questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a MINOR criteria in the 2015 revised Jones criteria in moderate to high risk population ?
questions.solution:
According to the modified Jones criteria (2015), in moderate to high-risk populations polyarthralgia is not a minor criterion. It is considered a major criteria.

Whereas in low-risk populations, polyarthralgia is considered as a minor criterion.

Related Pearl: Revised Jones criteria for diagnosis of Acute Rheumatic Fever (ARF)

Revised Jones criteria for the diagnosis of rheumatic fever are as follows:

Major criteria
Low-risk populations* Moderate- and high-risk populations*
   
Carditis- Clinical or subclinical Carditis- Clinical or subclinical
Arthritis- Polyarthritis only Arthritis- Polyarthritis/polyarthralgia/monoarthritis
Chorea Chorea
Erythema marginatum Erythema marginatum
Subcutaneous nodules Subcutaneous nodules
   
Minor criteria 
Polyarthralgia Monoarthralgia
Fever (≥38.5°C) Fever (≥38°C)
ESR ≥60 mm in the first hour and/or CRP ≥3.0 mg/dL ESR ≥30 mm/hr and/or CRP ≥3.0 mg/dL
Prolonged PR interval, after accounting for age variability (unless carditis is a major criterion) Prolonged PR interval, after accounting for age variability (unless carditis is a major criterion) 
   
For all patient populations with evidence of preceding Group A Streptococcal infection:(Increased ASLO/ anti-DNAse B titer or positive throat culture for group A streptococcus or positive rapid streptococcal carbohydrate antigen test) 
Diagnosis of initial ARF 2 Major criteria or 1 major plus 2 minor criteria
Diagnosis of recurrent ARF 2 Major or 1 major and 2 minor or 3 minor criteria

*Low-risk populations are those with ARF incidence ≤2 per 100 000 school-aged children or all-age rheumatic heart disease prevalence of ≤1 per 1000 population per year. If the incidence exceeds the given limit, then it is moderate-high risk populations.

questions.text: The most common cause of bladder outlet obstruction in a male child is
questions.solution:
The most common cause of bladder outflow obstruction in a male child is the posterior urethral valve (PUV). 

PUV is a membranous fold in the posterior urethra. They typically lie just distal to the verumontanum. It is the most common cause of bladder outlet obstruction in male newborns. PUV is thought to be due to the persistence of the urogenital membrane. 

Urethral obstruction will result in a dilated posterior urethral valve, dilated bladder, and bilateral hydronephrosis. Prenatally this appears as a keyhole sign during the ultrasound. It can also result in oligohydramnios. If the defect is not detected prenatally, they present postnatally either as a newborn or young infant with urinary tract symptoms, abdominal distension, or respiratory distress due to lung hypoplasia.

Untreated PUV may lead to chronic kidney disease, bladder dysfunction, and vesicoureteral reflux. 

Diagnosis is presumed by the presence of an elongated posterior valve during the voiding phase of the voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG).

The image shows a keyhole sign as seen in PUV prenatally. The white arrow points to the main hole and represents the distended urinary bladder. The black arrow points to the slit, which is the distended proximal urethra.

 

Other options

Options B and C- Urethral atresia and anterior urethral valve are rare congenital anomalies that can also lead to urinary obstruction.

Option D- Ureterocele is the cystic enlargement of the intramural ureter. It is common in females. They can present with features of urinary tract infection, bladder obstruction, or ureteral stones. Excretion urography will show cobra head appearance.

The image shown below depicts the "cobra head" sign in a patient with bilateral ureterocele.

questions.text: Which does 'I' stand for in the PALM-COEIN classification for abnormal uterine bleeding?
questions.solution:
The 'I' in the FIGO PALM-COEIN classification for abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) stands for iatrogenic causes.

AUB in the reproductive age group was previously known as dysfunctional uterine bleeding, however, that term is now obsolete. AUB can be acute or chronic:

  • Acute AUB - it can start sporadically or be superimposed on chronic AUB.
  • Chronic AUB - it lasts for 3-6 months minimum.

PALM-COEIN classification of AUB:

  • Polyp (AUB-P):
    • Endometrial polyps
    • Endocervical polyps
  • Adenomyosis (AUB-A)
  • Leiomyoma (AUB-L). Fibroids are further classified as:
    • Submucosal (SM)
    • Other (O)
  • Malignancy and hyperplasia (AUB-M) 
    • Endometrial hyperplasia 
    • Endometrial carcinoma
  • Coagulopathy (AUB-C)
    • von Willebrand's disease
    • Hemophilias
  • Ovarian causes (AUB-O)
    • PCOD
    • Hypothyroidism
    • Hyperprolactinemia.  
  • Endometrial causes (AUB-E)
    • Tubercular or chlamydial endometritis 
  • Iatrogenic causes (AUB-I)
    • Intrauterine contraceptive devices
    • Anticoagulants
    • Tricyclic antidepressants
  • Not yet classified (AUB-N) includes rare causes such as
    • Arteriovenous malformations 
    • Myometrial hypertrophy

questions.text: Which cardiac chamber enlargement is seen in the case of mitral stenosis on chest X-ray initially?
questions.solution:
The earliest changes seen on X-ray in MS are:

  • LA enlargement on the lateral and left anterior oblique views.
  • Straightening of the upper left border of the cardiac silhouette.
  • Posterior displacement of the esophagus by an enlarged LA.
  • Kerley B lines due to distention of interlobular septae and lymphatics with edema.

Enlargement of the pulmonary artery, right ventricle, and right atrium are commonly seen in patients with severe MS causing pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text: What is the ideal time for nuchal translucency evaluation?
questions.solution:
Nuchal translucency evaluation, a component of first-trimester aneuploidy screening, is done between 11-14 weeks.

It represents the maximum thickness of the subcutaneous translucent area between the skin and soft tissue, overlying the fetal spine, at the back of the neck. When the nuchal translucency is increased, the risk of fetal aneuploidy and structural anomalies such as heart defects is significantly elevated.

First trimester aneuploidy screening combines two maternal serum analytes and a sonographic measurement:

  1. Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)
  2. Pregnancy-associated plasma protein A (PAPP-A)
  3. Nuchal translucency (NT)

It is performed between 11 and 14 weeks of gestation. In cases of fetal Down syndrome, the first-trimester serum-free β-hCG level is higher and the PAPP-A level is lower. With trisomy 18 and trisomy 13, levels of both analytes are lower.

Note: Nuchal fold is a normal fold of skin seen at the back of the fetal neck during the second trimester of pregnancy. Increased nuchal fold thickness is associated with fetal aneuploidy.

questions.text: A 29-year-old G2P1 comes to the physician at 32 weeks of gestation. She underwent  OGTT(75 g of glucose) and her values were fasting 110 mg/dl and 2 hours of glucose at 180 mg/dl. Which among the following is the next step regarding the management of this patient?

choices.text: Induce labour due to risk of fetal macrosomia

questions.solution:
Since her values are more than the normal limits with a 75 g OGTT she is having gestational diabetes and the next step in the management is to admit her and start insulin.

The glucose tolerance test is considered the diagnostic test for gestational diabetes mellitus and insulin is the drug of choice for the treatment of gestational diabetes mellitus. It does not cross the placenta and tight glycemic control can typically be achieved.

Diagnosis of GDM with 75 g OGTT according to IADPSG is made if any one of the following are met:

  • Fasting: ≥92 mg/dl 
  • 1 hour: ≥180 mg/dl  
  • 2 hours: ≥153 mg/dl

The initial management of GDM is maternal nutrition therapy with diet and exercise. Insulin therapy is started if :

  • Fasting plasma glucose levels persistently ≥95 mg/dl or the 2-hour postprandial plasma glucose ≥120 mg/dL in women with gestational diabetes treated with maternal nutrition therapy.
  • Glucose levels on OGTT are in the range for overt diabetes.

Since this question does not have the option of Maternal nutrition therapy, the best step would be to start her on insulin.

The starting dose is typically 0.7 to 1 unit/kg/d and is given in divided doses. A combination of intermediate-acting and short-acting insulin may be used.

50% of women with gestational diabetes develop overt diabetes within 20 years. Hence, they are recommended to undergo screening & revaluation between 4-12 weeks postpartum.

Earlier, a two-step approach was used to diagnose GDM. In this, the first step (screening) is a 50-gram one-hour glucose challenge test (GCT). The patients having a positive result for this test were then subject to the second step, a 100-gram, three-hour oral glucose tolerance test (GTT), which is the diagnostic test for gestational diabetes mellitus. This has now been replaced by the one-step approach that omits the screening test and simplifies diagnostic testing by performing only a 75-gram, two-hour oral GTT.

questions.text: A young man presented with painful lesions as shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows confluent, red, pustular lesions in a single dermatome associated with severe pain is suggestive of herpes zoster or shingles. 

It is a segmental eruption due to the reactivation of latent varicella-zoster virus from dorsal root ganglia. An earlier infection with varicella is essential before zoster can occur. 

The first symptom of zoster is usually pain and it may be accompanied by fever, headache, malaise, and tenderness localized to areas of one or more dorsal roots. The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.

The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and nasopharynx. The thoracic dermatomes are most commonly affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.

Zoster is a self‐limiting infection but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post‐herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

Indications for antivirals in VZV (Acyclovir 800 mg):

  • Painful zoster infections in adults
  • Facial zoster at any age
  • Immunocompromised

Other options:

Option B: The lesions of the molluscum contagiosum are shiny, white, and hemispherical. It is umbilicated with a central pore. It is caused by poxvirus. 

The below image shows the lesions seen in Molluscum contagiosum

Option C: Herpes simplex virus are classified into two major antigenic types,

  • Type 1 (HSV-1) which is classically associated with facial infections;
  • Type 2(HSV-2) which is typically genital.

Below image shows small, closely grouped vesicles on an inflamed base and is characteristic of Herpes Labialis or Cold sore.

 

 

Option D: Lymphangiomas are dilated dermal lymphatics that blister onto the skin surface. The fluid is usually clear, but occasionally maybe blood-stained. Lymphangiomas may thrombose and get fibrosed, to form hard nodules in the long term. This may raise concerns about malignancy.

If lymphangiomas are <5 cm across, they are called lymphangioma circumscriptum (shown below), and they are called lymphangioma diffusum if they are more widespread.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the management of endometriosis?

choices.text: Primary surgery is preferred in infertile women because hormones delay pregnancy
Asymptomatic patients are observed over 6–8 months without any need of the infertility workup
Estrogen is the drug of choice for endometriosis
Not all symptomatic women need treatment

questions.solution:
Primary surgery is preferred in infertile women because hormones delay pregnancy. This is the only true statement.

Endometriosis is estrogen-dependent. Hence estrogen is not used in treatment.

Minimal asymptomatic cases are to be observed over 6–8 months and infertility in such cases should be investigated and treated if necessary.

All symptomatic women do need treatment.

Treatment of endometriosis:

Medical management

Minimal disease Moderate/Severe disease
DOC = NSAIDS DOC=GnRH agonist
OCPs (Pain with menstrual complaints) Progesterone (First drug to start)

Mnemonic to remember drugs used: GOLD GAP

  • G: GnRH analog
  • O: Oral contraceptive pills
  • L: Letrozole
  • D: Danazol
  • G: Gestrinone
  • A: Antiprogesterone-Mifepristone
  • P: Progesterone

Surgical management

  • Conservative surgery: Endometrial deposits are destroyed by electrocautery/laser.
  • Laparoscopic uterosacral nerve ablation (LUNA)
  • Radical surgery: Total hysterectomy with bilateral oopherectomy.

 Note:

  • Endometrioma is treated by laparoscopic management.

questions.text: The syndromic management of urethral discharge includes the treatment of_______
questions.solution:
Syndromic management of urethral discharge in males involves the treatment of gonorrhea and chlamydial infection.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

questions.text:
A COVID-19 positive man is rushed to the casualty due to severe breathlessness. Examination findings are suggestive of pneumonia and his vitals are- PR: 90/min, BP: 134/88 mmHg, RR: 32/min and SpO2: 86%. What will you advise this patient?

PR: 90/min

BP: 134/88 mmHg

RR: 22/min

Temperature: 101 F

SpO2: 86%
questions.solution: The patient is suffering from severe COVID-19 and hence has to be admitted to ICU. The disease is said to be severe when there is RR>30/min, breathlessness OR SpO2<90% on room air.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primi,  visits your clinic for regular antenatal check-up at 37 weeks of gestation. You perform the following grip by facing the feet of the patient. This  is known as
questions.solution:
The obstetric grip shown in the picture is the Fourth Leopold maneuver (also known as pelvic grip) and it is used to detect the degree of descent. This examination is done by facing the patient’s feet.

Fetal pole, lie, presenting part, engagement, and attitude of fetal head are assessed by Leopold's manoeuvres:

First Leopold (Fundal grip ):

  • Performed by facing the patient’s face
  • Assesses the uterine fundus.
  • Helps in identification of fetal lie and determination of fetal pole at the fundus.
  • The breech gives the sensation of a large, irregular mass. 
  • The head feels hard and round and is more mobile.

Second Leopold (Lateral grip ): 

  • Performed by facing the patient’s face
  • Assesses the fetal orientation.
  • The palms are placed on either side of the maternal abdomen, and gentle but deep pressure is exerted.
  • The back is felt on one side as a hard, resistant structure.
  • The fetal extremities are felt on the other side as numerous small, irregular, mobile parts are felt.
  • Fetal orientation can be determined by noting whether the back is directed anteriorly, transversely, or posteriorly.
  • The position of the anterior shoulder is mainly assessed by this grip.

Pawlik's grip (third Leopold):

  • Performed by facing the patient’s face.
  • Assesses the presenting part in respect to the true pelvis.
  • The thumb and fingers of one hand grasp the lower portion of the maternal abdomen just above the symphysis pubis.
  • If the presenting part is not engaged it can be grasped distinctly.

Pelvic grip (fourth Leopold):

  • Assesses the engagement, attitude of the fetal head and determines the degree of descent.
  • The examiner faces the mother's feet, and the fingertips of both hands are positioned on either side of the presenting part.
  • They exert inward pressure and then slide along the axis of the pelvic inlet.
  • It is the only grip performed facing the feet.

questions.text: A newborn presented with a tuft of hair over the lumbosacral region as shown below. During her pregnancy, the mother did not have an elevated serum alpha-fetoprotein level in her serum. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of a tuft of hair over the lower back in a newborn, along with the absence of elevated serum alpha-fetoprotein in the maternal serum during pregnancy suggests a likely diagnosis of spinal bifida occulta. 

Spina bifida occulta refers to fusion defects of the posterior part of the vertebral body. There is no associated protrusion of the spinal cord or meninges. These neonates are usually asymptomatic, without any neurological signs. They present only with a tuft of hair over the lower back. 

Elevated maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein during pregnancy suggests an open neural tube defect, such as meningocele, meningomyelocele, and encephalocele (Option A, B, and C).

Meningocele involves the midline protrusion of the meninges, while meningomyelocele involves the protrusion of the spinal cord with the meningeal covering.

The image below shows (from left to right) spina bifida occulta, meningocele, and meningomyelocele-

 

Encephalocele refers to the protrusion of intracranial tissue through a midline bony defect.

The two images below show babies with encephalocele i.e. midline neural tube defects of the cranial end-

questions.text: A man presents with a slowly progressive swelling over the past 1 and 1/2 years. On examination, it has a variable consistency and appears as shown in the image. What is the probable cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image showing the swelling lifting the ear lobe is suggestive of pleomorphic adenoma.

Pleomorphic adenoma is a painless, slowly growing, benign tumor that usually affects females more than males. It most commonly arises from the superficial lobe. It is unicentric in origin with a pseudo-capsule present. It is a radioresistant tumor.

Clinical features:

  • Lobulated, firm, elastic-to-hard in consistency
  • Well-defined margins
  • Free from deeper structures
  • With no facial nerve involvement

In case of deep lobe involvement, tonsils and faucial pillars will be pushed medially.

All tumors of the superficial lobe of the parotid gland should be managed by superficial parotidectomy.

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: Hemiplegia is commonly associated with infarction of the area of distribution of ____
questions.solution:
Hemiplegia is commonly associated with infarction of the area of distribution of middle cerebral artery.

Middle cerebral artery supplies the motor cortex responsible for sending the output to the motor neurons. Infarction in this territory leads to hemiplegia.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a feature of modified radical hysterectomy ?
questions.solution: • In modified radical hysterectomy (Type 2) upper 2cm of vagina is removed.

questions.text: The first region scanned in FAST:
questions.solution:
Pericardial (also known as subxiphoid) is the first area to be assessed in FAST.

Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (FAST) aims to identify intra-abdominal free fluid (assumed to be hemoperitoneum in the context of trauma) allowing for an immediate transfer to OT for surgery or for CT for further workup.

The standard order of evaluation is:

  • Pericardial
  • Right flank (hepatorenal view or "Morison's pouch")
  • Left flank (perisplenic view)
  • Pelvic (retrovesical views)

E-FAST/ Extended FAST assesses thoracic region (pneumothorax and hemothorax evaluations).

questions.text: You are a medical officer working at primary health center(PHC). You refer some of the complicated cases to a secondary or tertiary hospital. This way of development of referral services by establishing proper linkages between the PHC and higher-level center, was developed by which committee?
questions.solution:
The committee that is responsible for developing 'referral services complex' is the Shrivastav committee. 

The Shrivastav committee was started in 1974 by the Ministry of Health and Family Planning. It is also known as the 'Group on Medical Education and Support Manpower'. The goals of the program are as follows:

  1. Devise a training program to produce health assistants that can be the link between the medical practitioners and multipurpose workers in order to form an effective health care team
  2. Suggest steps to improve the medical educational process based on national requirements
  3. Other suggestions that can help achieve the above-mentioned goals

As part of this committee, bands of para-professional and semi-professional health workers were formed. These individuals were part of the community already as postmasters and school teachers. They were trained to provide simple preventative and curative services to the community. 

Multipurpose health workers and health assistants were trained to form the bridge between the community workers and doctors. A 'referral services complex' was also installed to help strengthen referrals from the PHCs to the regional hospitals.

Finally, they established a Medical and Health Education Commission which focused on improving medical education with the help of the University Grants Commission.  

At least one male and female health care worker should be available per 5000 population. 

Other options: 

Option A - The Chadah committee outlined the responsibility of PHCs in the National Malaria Eradication Programme. They provided one basic health worker for 10,000 population. 

Option C - The Jungalwalla committee is also called the Committee on Integration of Health Services. It implemented common seniority and a unified cadre. They ensured equal pay for equal work and special pay for specialized work.

Option D - Mudaliar committee recommended that district hospitals be strengthened by adding specialist services. They also added regional deputy and assistant directors to supervise district medical and health officers. They limited the population served by each health center.

questions.text: A mother of five, brings her youngest child, an 18-month-old girl, for evaluation. The child appears very thin with minimal fat distribution. There is severe wasting of the shoulders, arms, buttocks, and thighs as shown in the below image. The middle-upper arm circumference is less than 11.5cm. The child is alert and irritable. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The alert and irritable child with severe fat wasting in the areas of the shoulders, arms, buttocks, and thighs is likely to have marasmus. 

Marasmus is a type of severe protein-energy malnutrition which occurs due to insufficient calorie intake. It is characterized by severe wasting of fat and muscles. The child appears to be very thin,  having a 'skin and bones' appearance with no fat. 

The loss of buccal fat leads to the 'monkey facies' or 'old man face' due to its aged and wrinkled appearance. 'Baggy pants appearance' is due to the presence of loose skin in the buttocks that hangs low. 

Other features that may be present are hypotension, hypothermia, and bradycardia as well as micronutrient deficiencies. 

Diagnosis of severe acute malnutrition is made with the help of anthropometry.

  • Weight for height is below -3 standard deviations for the mean on the World Health Organization (WHO) chart  or,
  • Presence of bipedal edema or,
  • Middle-upper arm circumference (MUAC) is less than 115mm (in the red zone of the tape as shown below). 

 

The children should be assessed for the following: 

  • Severe edema 
  • Low appetite (failed appetite test) 
  • Medical complications 
  • One or more danger sign

If any of the above are present, the child should be treated as a case of complicated severe acute malnutrition and should have inpatient management. Uncomplicated cases can have supervised home management. 

The WHO recommends testing hemoglobin, total blood count, peripheral blood smear, blood glucose, serum albumin, electrolytes, stool microscopy with culture, parasitic evaluation, retroviral testing, and urine microscopy with culture. 

Other options: 

Option A - Kwashiorkor is another type of protein-energy malnutrition that is characterized mainly by pitting edema starting in the legs and feet that spread to the hands and face. They also show skin changes characterized by increased pigmentation and desquamation. They do not show signs of hunger and are difficult to feed. The weight for height may be normal. The following image shows the edema and the skin changes seen in Kwashiorkor.

 

Option C - Chronic pancreatitis can mimic protein-energy malnutrition. It can occur due to cystic fibrosis and obstruction of the pancreatic ducts due to roundworms. This would present with prolonged abdominal pain, weight loss, and steatorrhea. 

Option D - Marasmic kwashiorkor is a mixed form of malnutrition that presents with features of both marasmus and kwashiorkor. There will be edema, and growth stunting with less severe hair and skin changes of kwashiorkor.

questions.text: Identify the device:
questions.solution:
The device is Automated External Defibrillator (AED).

This is a special medical device that is commonly used for recognizing the absence/presence of rapid ventricular tachycardia or ventricular fibrillation. With no need for intervention by an operator, it determines whether an electrical shock right to the heart must be performed (defibrillation).

An automatic external defibrillator can be used on those victims, who are unconscious and aren’t breathing in a normal way. As a rule, it is used together with CPR in cases of sudden cardiac arrest. It is forbidden to use it on patients, who are less than eight years old or on that weighing less than 55 pounds.

questions.text: You have just performed defibrillation in a patient with ventricular fibrillation. According to the ACLS guidelines, what should be your next step?
questions.solution:
Chest compressions should be resumed immediately following shock delivery.

Pulse check and reanalysis of the cardiac rhythm is performed only after 2 minutes of chest compression and rescue breaths. This is because the heart is temporarily stunned by a defibrillator shock and so chest compressions would benefit the patient by providing coronary blood flow during this period.

Defibrillation involves delivering an electrical current between two pads placed on the chest so as to interrupt disorganized cardiac activity and restore an organized cardiac rhythm or asystole for at least 5 seconds. It is of utmost necessity to defibrillate immediately because the chances of survival decrease by 7-10% every minute without defibrillation.

If after 2 minutes, the rhythm remains the same, then another shock is delivered. Chest compression and rescue breaths are resumed and 1 mg epinephrine is administered. Consideration is given for an advanced airway placement.

If after 2 minutes the rhythm still remains the same, the first dose of amiodarone 300mg bolus is given.

With the next cycle of CPR, a shock is delivered and 1 mg of epinephrine is given. And with the cycle of CPR after that, shock is delivered and the second dose of amiodarone- 150mg is given

questions.text: Sleep apnea is defined as a temporary pause in breathing during sleep lasting at least _______
questions.solution:
Sleep apnea is defined as a temporary pause in breathing during sleep lasting at least 10 seconds.

Sleep apneas can be further divided into:

  1. Obstructive apneas - Sleep apnea with persistent respiratory effort.
  2. Central apneas - Sleep apnea with an absence of respiratory effort.

The gold standard for the diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnea/hypoxia syndrome (OSAHS) is an overnight polysomnogram (PSG).

questions.text:
A 23 yr old gravida 1, para 0 at 25 weeks gestation, presents with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and vomiting for the past 2 days. BP-104/72mm Hg, PR-72bpm. There is generalized edema. Peripheral smear shows hemolysis. Lab values are given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Leukocyte count: 10,500/mm3
Platelet count: 62000/mm3
Hematocrit: 26%
AST: 90 IU/L
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is HELLP syndrome.

The typical presentation of right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, lab findings of thrombocytopenia, low hematocrit, and peripheral smear finding of hemolysis, point towards a diagnosis of  HELLP ( Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelets) syndrome.

Although related to preeclampsia, hypertension and proteinuria may be absent or minimal in HELLP syndrome.

Tennessee criteria used in the diagnosis of HELLP syndrome :

  • Platelet count <1 lakh,
  • AST >70 IU/L,
  • LDH >600 IU/L

Risk factors for HELLP syndrome include

  • Preeclampsia
  • abnormal placentation
  • family history of HELLP syndrome
  • elevated levels of fetal mRNA for FLT l (vascular endothelial growth factor rfi­ receptor 1) and
  • Multiparity
  • Maternal age >34 years
  • European descent
  • History of previous poor pregnancy outcomes

Laboratory evaluation in HELLP:

  • Complete blood cell (CBC) count: Thrombocytopenia, anemia with possible reticulocytosis
  • Coagulation studies: Normal prothrombin time, 50% may have prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time
  • Peripheral smear: Schistocytes, helmet cells, and burr cells secondary to microangiopathic hemolytic anemia
  • Serum aspartate aminotransferase/alanine aminotransferase (AST/ALT) levels: Elevated secondary to liver dysfunction
  • Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level: Elevated secondary to liver dysfunction or hemolysis
  • Elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN)/creatinine with acute renal failure
  • Bilirubin level: Increased secondary to hemolysis
  • Haptoglobin level: Decreased secondary to hemolysis
  • Fibrinogen levels: Low secondary to increased coagulation
  • D-dimer: Increased due to fibrinolysis/DIC

HELLP syndrome may lead to the development of DIC which manifests as increased fibrin split products and decreased fibrinogen levels.

Other options:

Disorder

 AST (SGOT) U/L Bilirubin (mg/dL)
Cholestasis of pregnancy Up to 200 1–5
Acute fatty liver of pregnancy 200–800 4–10
Hepatitis 2000+ 5–20

questions.text: Double bleb sign seen in early pregnancy is due to :
questions.solution:
The double bleb sign is due to the yolk sac and amniotic sac.

On ultrasonographic examination, a gestational sac may contain the yolk sac and amniotic sac, appearing like two small bubbles. This is known as the double bleb sign. The embryonic disc is located between the yolk sac and the amniotic sac. It is an important feature of an intrauterine pregnancy.

Other options:

In a twin pregnancy, the chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed with the help of an ultrasound examination.

  • In dichorionic gestation, the twins are separated by amniotic membranes and an intervening chorion. So, a thicker twin peak sign or lambda (λ) sign is formed at the point at which the amnions meet the placenta.
  • In monochorionic diamniotic gestation, the twins are separated only by the two amniotic membranes with no intervening chorion. So, a thin T sign is formed at the point at which the amnions meet the placenta.

Heterotopic pregnancy is a condition in which a normal uterine pregnancy co-exists with an extrauterine (ectopic) pregnancy. Although heterotopic pregnancy can occur spontaneously, it is more likely after artificial reproductive technology (ART) and ovulation induction.

Below image shows heterotopic pregnancy with 2 sacs, one inside the uterus (white arrow) and the other in the cervix (black arrows).

questions.text: Which of the following describes the theme of World health day 2022?
questions.solution:
the theme of World health day 2022 is Our Planet, Our Health

The theme of World health day 2018 as well as 2019- Universal health coverage.

World health day 2017- Depression: Let's talk

World health day 2016- Halt the rise, beat diabetes

World health day is observed on the 7th of April every year.

questions.text: A patient, who is on treatment for hypertension came to the OPD for follow up. Which of the following drugs must be preferably avoided in patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis?
questions.solution:
ACE inhibitors are preferably avoided in patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis.

Bilateral renal artery stenosis (BRAS) is the narrowing of both renal arteries, leading to reduced kidney perfusion and activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS), causing hypertension and potential renal dysfunction.

In patients with BRAS, ACE inhibitors (e.g., enalapril) and ARBs (e.g., losartan) should generally be avoided as they can reduce glomerular filtration pressure by dilating the efferent arteriole, potentially leading to acute kidney injury (AKI). Additionally, direct renin inhibitors (e.g., aliskiren) and potassium-sparing diuretics should be used cautiously due to the risk of worsening renal function and hyperkalemia.

Other options:

Option B, C and D: Diuretics, beta blockers and calcium channel blockers are antihypertensive drugs that can be used in bilateral renal artery stenosis.

questions.text: A primigravida delivered a baby at term with a birth weight of 1.9 kg via normal vaginal delivery. The placenta delivered appears as shown in the image below. What is this condition known as?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a circumvallate placenta. The membranes at the periphery are thickened and consist of a double fold of chorion and amnion.

Normally, the chorionic plate and basal plates are of the same size. In conditions of extrachorial placentation, the chorionic plate is smaller than the basal plate. There are two types of extrachorial placentation:

  • Circummarginate placenta -  In this type, the space between the fetal membranes and the basal plate is filled up by fibrin and old hemorrhage. 
  • Circumvallate placenta - In this type, the peripheral chorion is thickened into a ridge composed of a double fold of chorion and amnion. Complications associated with circumvallate placenta are:
    • Preterm delivery
    • Abortions
    • IUGR
    • Antepartum hemorrhage
    • Retained placenta and membranes

Option A: Placenta succenturiata has one or more small lobes of the placenta placed at varying distances from the main placental margins.

Options B & D: Placenta marginata or circummarginate placenta - a thin margin is present between the chorionic and basal plates.

questions.text: Mrs. Kokila presents with a lump in her left breast at 10 weeks of pregnancy. Ultrasound and trucut biopsy revealed the presence of invasive ductal carcinoma. How will you manage this patient?

choices.text: Perform mastectomy and start chemotherapy immediately after delivery
Mastectomy followed by hormonal therapy in the second and third trimester
Mastectomy followed by chemotherapy in the second and third trimester

questions.solution:
A pregnant woman who is diagnosed with breast cancer in first trimester is best managed by mastectomy along with chemotherapy in the second and third trimester.

Pregnancy-associated breast cancer is defined as breast cancer that is diagnosed during pregnancy or within 1 year of postpartum.

It is the most common non-gy­necologic malignancy associated with pregnancy. Most patients present with a painless mass in the breast with or without bloody nipple discharge.

Diagnosis is done by ultrasonography and tissue biopsy.

Treatment of breast cancer in pregnancy:

  • Breast cancer in pregnancy is mainly treated by mastectomy in any trimester along with chemotherapy in the second and third trimesters.
  • Since radiotherapy is a component of breast conservation therapy, it is contraindicated in the first trimester of pregnancy. However, breast-conserving lumpectomy and axillary lymph node dissection with chemotherapy can be done in the second and third trimesters of pregnancy followed by radiation after delivery. 
  • Radiotherapy and hormonal therapies are absolutely contraindicated during pregnancy because of teratogenicity. They can be initiated after delivery.

questions.text: The chromosomal abnormality associated in a neonate with prominent occiput, clenched fist with overlapping fingers, and rocker-bottom feet is most probably _________
questions.solution:
Prominent occiput, clenched fist with overlapping fingers, and rocker-bottom feet are all features of Edwards syndrome, i.e., Trisomy 18.

Trisomy 18 - Edwards syndrome:

  • Low birth weight
  • Closed fists with index finger overlapping the 3rd digit and the 5th digit overlapping the 4th
  • Narrow hips with limited abduction
  • Short sternum
  • Rocker-bottom feet
  • Microcephaly
  • Prominent occiput
  • Micrognathia
  • Cardiac and renal malformations
  • Intellectual disability

questions.text: All of the following drugs are useful in the management of antiphospholipid syndrome except
questions.solution:
Glucocorticoids are not useful in the management of antiphospholipid syndrome (APS).

The clinical manifestations in APS occur due to the activation of coagulation and thrombus formation. Therefore, anticoagulants and antiplatelet agents are the mainstays in the treatment. Important drugs used are:

  • Warfarin- It is an anticoagulant that inhibits Vitamin K dependant epoxidase.
  • Low molecular weight heparins (LMWH)- Warfarin cannot be used in pregnancy due to its teratogenicity. In these situations, LMWH are used for anticoagulation.
  • Aspirin- It is an antiplatelet agent 
  • Hydroxychloroquine- It is an immunomodulatory agent that can be used to prevent recurrent thrombosis
  • Statins

Note- The only condition where corticosteroids are beneficial is catastrophic APS. It is a life-threatening rapidly progressive thromboembolic disease involving simultaneously three or more organs. It is seen in very few patients.

questions.text: A primigravida was diagnosed with a prolonged second stage of labor due to the fetus being in occipitoposterior position. The obstetrician decided to give a posterior mediolateral cut at the introitus to facilitate delivery. Which of the following instruments would she use for the same?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of prolonged second stage of labor can be managed by performing an episiotomy. In the given figure, the instrument marked as "D" corresponds to episiotomy scissors.

An episiotomy is done to prevent posterior extention leading to obstetric anal sphincteric injuries.

Related Pearl: Mediolateral Episiotomy

It begins within 3 mm of the midline in the posterior fourchette and is directed laterally at an angle of at least 60 degrees from the midline. This yields an incision of 45 degrees off the midline.

It is essentially an inflicted second-degree perineal tear.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering those muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

Advantage: Lesser risk of anal sphincter laceration, hence it is preferred over median episiotomy.

Disadvantage: Increased blood loss and causes more perineal pain and dyspareunia.

questions.text: The following are considered clean areas of a Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) except
questions.solution:
The front of the face shield is considered to be a contaminated area of the PPE.

The areas that are considered clean are the parts that will be touched while removing a PPE

  • Inside the gloves 
  • Inside and back of the gown including the ties
  • Ties or earpieces of the mask, goggles, and face shields

The areas that are considered contaminated are 

  • Outside front and sleeves of the isolation gown 
  • Front of goggles, mask, respirator, and face shield
  • Outside of the gloves

questions.text: 4R’s of Radiotherapy are:
questions.solution:
In general, success or failure of standard clinical radiation treatment is determined by the 4 R’s of radiobiology: repair of DNA damage, redistribution of cells in the cell cycle, repopulation, and reoxygenation of hypoxic tumor areas.

5th R of radiotherapy is radiosensitivity.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about retrosternal goitre?

choices.text: Operated in all patients regardless of symptoms
Sternal incision is always required to operate
It receives blood supply from the thoracodorsal artery
Most of the retrosternal goitres can be removed by a neck incision

questions.solution:
Most of the retrosternal goitres can be removed by neck incision (transcervical). 

Option A: Surgical removal of the retrosternal goitre is indicated in patients with significant airway compression, in young patients who have symptoms such as dyspnoea or dysphagia. 

Option B: Median sternotomy approach is indicated in:

  • Primary mediastinal goitre
  • Malignant retrosternal goitre
  • Very large retrosternal goitre
  • Recurrence in the mediastinum

For a primary mediastinal goitre whose boundaries are completely within the chest, resection is often achieved through median sternotomy or thoracotomy to ensure that the vessels supplying the tumour are properly ligated. Removing the tumour through a cervical approach can result in uncontrolled bleeding and is generally avoided. 

Option C: Blood supply to retrosternal goitre is from the thyroid vessels (secondary).

questions.text: A 30-year old woman, who takes oral contraceptive pills regularly, presented with a history of headache, 1 episode of generalised seizures and confusion. On examination, she was found to have papilledema and focal neurological deficits. A  contrast-enhanced CT of the head shows the following finding. What could be the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The above mentioned clinical scenario, in this patient with a history of oral contraceptive use, is suggestive of cerebral venous thrombosis.

Cerebral venous thrombosis is commonly seen in hypercoagulable states such as:

  • Oral contraceptive pill use
  • Pregnancy and puerperium
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Dehydration
  • Intracranial infections.

It presents with:

  • Headache (most common)
  • Seizures
  • Intracranial Hypertension
  • Focal neurological Deficits
  • Altered Mental status

MR venography is used for diagnosis.

The below image shows the empty delta sign seen on CECT or MRI with contrast in patients with sagittal sinus thrombosis.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 12 weeks of gestation presents with spotting PV, hyperemesis, and lower abdominal pain for the past 2 days. USG done is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and USG showing snowstorm appearance is suggestive of a complete hydatidiform mole. 

The snowstorm appearance is due to an echogenic uterine mass that has numerous anechoic cystic spaces. Fetus and amniotic sac are absent. 

Investigations for molar pregnancy are:

  • USG - shows snowstorm appearance
  • Serum β hCG - elevated to >2 MoM (multiples of median) for corresponding gestational age
  • Histological examination of products of conception

Snowstorms in radiology:

  • Complete hydatiform mole (ultrasound)
  • Extracapsular breast implant rupture (ultrasound)
  • Carcinoma thyroid - pulmonary metastases (chest X-ray).

questions.text: Patients with which of the following tumors are best treated with radiotherapy?
questions.solution:
Patients diagnosed with seminoma are best treated with radiotherapy, as it is a highly radiosensitive tumor. 

Related Pearl: Radiosensitive and Radioresistant Tumors

Highly radiosensitive tumors are

  • Lymphoma
  • Seminoma
  • Myeloma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma
  • Wilm’s tumour

 Highly radioresistant tumors are

  • Melanoma
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Pancreatic carcinoma
  • Hepatic carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma

questions.text: Relaxin during pregnancy is secreted by ______
questions.solution:
Relaxin is secreted by corpus luteum ,decidua, chorion during pregnancy.

Whereas, in a non pregnant state it is secreted by corpus luteum and breast.

questions.text: A young man with idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura is posted for splenectomy. His platelet count is 32000 per cubic millimeter. What is the best time to transfuse platelets in this patient?

choices.text: Immediately after the ligation of splenic artery
Immediately after the ligation of splenic vein

questions.solution:
The best time to transfuse platelets in this patient is immediately after ligation of the splenic artery.

The platelets are destroyed by the spleen within one hour of transfusion, and the splenic artery is the major vessel that brings blood to the spleen. Therefore, the best time to transfuse the platelets is immediately after the ligation of the splenic artery.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the procedure performed with the following set of instruments?

choices.text: Best placement of the tube for suctioning is postpyloric
It is contraindicated in significant facial trauma
Length is measured from tip of nose to ear to xiphisternum
Abdominal x-ray is the best way to confirm position

questions.solution:
The given instrument tray shows instruments required for insertion of a nasogastric tube which is placed before the pylorus when used for suction to avoid damage to the duodenum.

Nasogastric tubes play a standard role in treating intestinal obstruction and can also be used to provide nutritional support. The commonly used method to determine the length of a nasogastric tube is the NEX method: the tip of the nose to ear to xiphisternum.

NEX method:

  • Nose–Ear–Xiphisternum 
  • The tube length should be estimated before insertion.
  • Place the exit port of the tube at the tip of the nose. Extend tube to the earlobe, and then to xiphisternum.

Approximate length to be inserted: 55cms

Ideally, Ryle's tube is inserted in the sitting position with the neck slightly flexed. Confirmation of the correct position is done by the following:

  • Auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air
  • An abdominal x-ray is the best way to confirm the location of the tube

The ideal location for an NG tube placed for suction is within the stomach because placement past the pylorus can cause damage to the duodenum. The ideal location for an NG feeding tube is postpyloric to decrease the risk of aspiration.

Indications for NG tube :

  • Aspiration of gastric fluid
  • Gastric decompression
  • Feeding
  • Administration of medication
  • Bowel irrigation

Contraindications:

Absolute:

  • Severe midface trauma
  • Recent nasal surgery

Relative:

  • Coagulation abnormality
  • Esophageal varices
  • Recent banding of esophageal varices
  • Anastomoses in stomach and esophagus

Instruments tray used for nasogastric tube insertion:

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman was diagnosed with Hashimoto's thyroiditis and started on levothyroxine 2 weeks ago. She now presents to your clinic with abdominal pain, dizziness and weight loss. Her current appearance and her appearance last month are shown below respectively. Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with severe dizziness, weight loss and a history of autoimmune thyroiditis with the image showing hyperpigmentation of the skin, points to a diagnosis of Addison’s disease and hyperglycemia is not a feature of this condition.

The clinical features of Addison’s disease include:

Hormone

Clinical features
Hypoaldosteronism

Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, salt craving
Dizziness, postural hypotension
AKI due to volume depletion
Hyponatremia
Hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis
Hypocortisolism Anorexia, weight loss, fatigue, myalgia, arthralgia
Fever (increased IL-1)
Depression
Postural hypotension
Hypoglycemia
Hyponatremia (loss of feedback inhibition of ADH)
Slightly increased TSH (loss of feedback inhibition)
Hypoandrogenism Loss of libido
  Loss of pubic and axillary hair
Elevated ACTH Hyperpigmentation

Levothyroxine can precipitate adrenal insufficiency or crisis in undiagnosed patients. In patients with concurrent adrenal insufficiency and hypothyroidism, a course of steroids must be given before giving thyroid replacement.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents to the orthopedician with complaints of painful swelling below the knee joint.  An X-Ray was obtained which is given below. Which of the following is the preferred treatment modality for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows an expansile, eccentric, sub-articular lesion with soap-bubble appearance suggestive of a giant cell tumour. The treatment of choice for this condition is extended curettage and bone grafting.

GCT in the relatively insignificant bone like distal ulna, clavicle, proximal fibula is treated by resection without reconstruction.

Bisphosphonates have been shown to reduce the proliferation of osteoclasts and hence have shown to stabilize local and metastatic disease. Radiation can be used for spinal or sacral tumors.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the given image?

choices.text: It is inserted by withdrawal technique
The copper in this device has a surface area of 380 square mm
It is used in emergency contraception
It has a life-span of 5 years

questions.solution:
The given image is CuT 380 A as it has copper in both the stem as well as the horizontal arms and it has the highest life span of 10 years.

Copper T-380A (Paragard):

It is named so for the 380 mm2 of copper surface area. A higher surface area of copper results in higher contraceptive efficacy. 

It has a plastic T-shaped core with copper placed around the vertical stem and horizontal arms. A silver core within the copper sheath is included to prevent fragmentation of the copper, extending the lifespan of the Copper T-380A.

The frame is connected to a monofilament thread that protrudes through the cervical canal into the upper vagina. This facilitates easy removal and allows the user to ensure that the IUD remains in the uterus.

If an IUCD is inserted within 7 days after coitus, it serves as an emergency contraceptive and is more effective than levonorgestrel/ulipristal acetate regimens.

questions.text: The Nuclear scan used for the detection of Meckel’s diverticulum:
questions.solution:
• Tc 99m Pertechnetate is used for detection of Meckel's diverticulum.
  • Uses of Tc-99m pertechnetate:
    • Thyroid imaging
    • Meckel scan
    • Testicle imaging
    • Parathyroid imaging for distinguishing from thyroid gland
    • Gastric emptying studies, intestinal and rectal functional studies.

questions.text: A series of speeches on a selected subject is called_______.
questions.solution:
A symposium is a series of lectures on a selected subject by experts after which the audience is allowed to ask questions (no discussion is involved).

A workshop is a series of meetings with emphasis on individual work within the group, with the use of external consultants or experts.

Role playing is the dramatization of social situations for health education by those taking part in it.

Seminars are similar to conferences and it incorporates a variety of methods like speeches, discussions for health education, and may last for half a day to a week.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument used in Ilizarov ring fixator.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Kirschner wire (K-wire).

Kirschner wire or K-wire has multiple uses. Insertion is stress-free, associated with less soft tissue damage and allows for early exercises after removal. The diameter of the K-wire is 1 to 3 mm. The wire is pointed at both ends for both antegrade and retrograde insertion. The shape of the tips could be trocar or diamond or threaded.

Uses of K-wire are:

  • To fix fractures in children
  • To give traction e.g. for olecranon fracture
  • To fix small bone fractures
  • In llizarov ring fixator

Related Pearl: Orthopedic Instruments

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with benign prostatic hypertrophy underwent TURP.  An hour later, he was found to have an altered sensorium and had several bouts of vomiting. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
The most probable cause for the above-mentioned symptoms is water intoxication also known as transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) syndrome. 

Absorption of water into the circulation at the time of transurethral urethral resection can lead to :

  • Hyponatremia, which may manifest as confusion, nausea, and vomiting
  • Congestive cardiac failure
  • Hemolysis 

It is managed by fluid restriction.

The use of isotonic glycine for irrigation during resection reduces the incidence of water intoxication.

questions.text: Which of the following casts are associated with a poor prognosis?
questions.solution:
Broad casts are associated with a poor prognosis.

They refer to wider waxy casts that are seen in advanced chronic kidney disease. It implies dilation of the tubules.

Epithelial casts consist of large epithelial cells and are seen in acute tubular necrosis, and acute interstitial nephritis.

WBC casts consist of leukocytes and is seen in pyelonephritis and acute interstitial nephritis. 

Hyaline casts are seen in non-specific conditions and prerenal failure.

questions.text: The most common site of branchial cyst is ______.

choices.text: Junction of upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle
Junction of middle and lower third of the sternomastoid muscle
Between the two heads of the sternomastoid muscle

questions.solution:
The most common site of a branchial cyst is at the junction of the upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle at its anterior border.

Branchial cyst develops from the vestigial remnants of the second branchial cleft. It is usually lined by squamous epithelium and contains thick, turbid fluid full of cholesterol crystals. It is fluctuant and may transilluminate to a lesser extent when it contains clear fluid.

A branchial fistula may be acquired or congenital. The congenital fistula is seen at the junction of the middle and lower third of the sternomastoid. An acquired fistula is usually seen in cases of incomplete surgery for the branchial cyst or spontaneous rupture, and it is seen at the same site as the cyst.

The below image shows a large right-sided branchial cyst.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most dependent part of a female?
questions.solution:
The rectouterine pouch, which is also called the pouch of Douglas is the most dependent part of a female.

Peritoneum of the female pelvis:

In females, the peritoneum covers the anterior and anterolateral surfaces of the rectum, uterus, and urinary bladder. Spaces found in the female pelvis are:

Pararectal fossae: Present on either side of the rectum. They are limited laterally by the peritoneum that covers the uterosacral ligaments. 

Paravesical fossae: Present on either side of the bladder. It is limited laterally by the peritoneum which covers the round ligament of the uterus.

Rectouterine pouch (pouch of Douglas): The peritoneum which covers the anterior surface of the rectum is reflected anteriorly to cover the posterior surface of the posterior fornix of the vagina and the uterus, forming a rectouterine pouch.

Vesicouterine pouch: The peritoneum covering the fundus and body of the uterus, is reflected anteriorly to cover the posterosuperior surface of the bladder forming a vesicouterine pouch.

Ovarian fossa: It is a shallow depression in the peritoneal lining of the lateral pelvic wall between the peritoneal ridges. It is formed by the obliterated umbilical arteries anteriorly, the ureter posteriorly, and the external iliac vessels above. It lies behind the lateral attachment of the broad ligament and contains the ovary in nulliparous females.

questions.text: You notice the following lesion in the forearm of an otherwise normal newborn. The lesion is caused because of:

choices.text: A viral infection transmitted from mother to the fetus
A bacterial infection transmitted from the mother to the fetus
Vigorous in utero sucking upon the affected part
An autoimmune condition in the newborn

questions.solution:
The image shows Sucking Blisters and are caused due to vigorous in utero sucking on the affected part.

They are usually present upon the upper-limb.

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

10. Hymenal tags

11. Physiological phimosis

12. Conjunctival hemorrhage

13. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding systemic Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis?
questions.solution:
Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) factor is negative in systemic JIA. It is positive in a subtype of polyarthritic type of JIA.

Systemic JIA is characterized by a fever of at least 2 weeks and Arthritis in 1 or more joints + at least one of 

  • Evanescent erythematous rash
  • Prominent visceral involvement, including hepatosplenomegaly
  • Generalized lymphadenopathy
  • Serositis

questions.text: Which of the following is not an early complication of fracture?
questions.solution:
Complex regional pain syndrome -CRPS(earlier known as Reflex sympathetic dystrophy or Sudeck's dystrophy or algodystrophy) is a late complication of fracture. Rest options are early complications

CRPS is divided into 2 types. CRPS type 1 occurs after trivial trauma or fracture and is explained below.

It occurs as a sequela of trauma and presents as a swollen, tender, and painful condition. It progressively undergoes atrophy of skin, muscle, and even nail over weeks resulting in fixed deformity at last. X-rays classically show spotty or patchy rarefaction. Earlier recognition and treatment initiation makes the prognosis relatively better.  Long term physiotherapy together with analgesics and anti-inflammatory drugs form the mainstay of treatment. Ganglion blockers in resistant cases can improve the condition.

CRPS type 2 is related to causalgia after nerve injury.

Other options:

Fat embolism syndrome-Fat embolism is the presence of fat globules in vital organs and peripheral circulation after fracture of the long bone or other major trauma.The classical clinical triad consists of respiratory distress,neurological abnormalities and petechial haemorrhages.

 

Related Pearl: Acute compartment and Crush syndrome

1. Acute Compartment Syndrome

Acute compartment syndrome is an elevation of the intracompartmental pressure (ICP) which increases the risk for tissue ischemia and necrosis.

Causes: Fractures (70%) and severe soft tissue injuries (30%). Common fractures causing compartment syndrome include tibial diaphyseal (most common), distal radius, and forearm fractures. 

Pathology: Increased pressure in one of the osseofascial compartments due to bleeding, oedema or inflammation. A vicious cycle of ischemia → edema→ ischemia leading to necrosis of the muscles and nerves within the compartment in 6 hours or less. 

Clinical features: Five Ps: Pain, Paraesthesia, Pallor, Paralysis and Pulselessness. 

Management: Fasciotomy to decompress the threatened compartment if the differential pressure (ΔP) goes < 30 mmHg. 

 

2. Crush syndrome 

Crush syndrome is the systemic manifestation of muscle necrosis. It is commonly caused due to prolonged external compression of an extremity. 

Causes: Crush injuries sustained during motor vehicle accidents, earthquakes, mining and other occupational accidents.

Pathology: Underperfusion of muscle causes myonecrosis. When the limb is freed, there is a release of toxic metabolites causing reperfusion injury. Reactive oxygen metabolites create further tissue injury. Free myoglobin can get precipitated in the renal glomeruli. 

Clinical features: The affected limb is pulseless, red, swollen and blistered. Sensation and muscle power may be lost. There can be signs of impaired renal function, metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia and hypocalcaemia.

Management: Encouraging high urine output, alkalization of the urine, hemofiltration, radical excision of dead muscles, fasciotomy if there is compartment syndrome.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with hemoptysis, proteinuria, and the clinical presentation given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing saddle nose deformity along with hemoptysis, and proteinuria is suggestive of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis).

Involvement of upper respiratory tract in granulomatosis with polyangiitis manifests as:

  • Paranasal sinusitis, serous otitis media
  • Nasal ulcers, purulent or bloody nasal discharge
  • Nasal perforation leading to the destruction of septum and saddle nose deformity
  • Subglottic tracheal stenosis

questions.text: A 35-year-old man develops a fever, headache, focal seizures and right hemiparesis. MRI shows hyperintensity in the left frontotemporal region. Which of the following is true about the CSF findings?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of Herpes simplex encephalitis (HSV).

HSV causes hemorrhagic necrosis of inferomedial temporal and frontal lobe. 

Both HSV 1 and HSV 2 cause Herpes simplex encephalitis. Patients present with fever, headache, seizures, personality, and behavioral changes.
CSF shows lymphocytic pleocytosis, moderately elevated protein levels and normal glucose concentration.
EEG shows periodic lateralized spike-wave discharges.
The drug of choice for HSV encephalitis is Acyclovir.

questions.text: All of the following characteristics are found in pleural effusion fluid of a Rheumatoid Arthritis patient except:
questions.solution:
A low glucose(not high) would be expected in the pleural effusion fluid of a patient with an exudative effusion, as would be found in Rheumatoid arthritis. 

Light’s criteria are used to distinguish between exudative and transudative pleural effusions.

An exudative pleural effusion satisfies at least one of the following criteria.

  • Pleural fluid protein / serum protein > 0.5
  • Pleural fluid LDH / serum LDH > 0.6
  • Pleural fluid LDH more than 2/3rds upper limit of normal for serum

questions.text: Which of the following statements about femoral hernia is true?

choices.text: All femoral hernias should be repaired
Femoral vein lies medial to the sac

questions.solution:
All femoral hernias should be repaired and incarcerated femoral hernias should have the hernia sac contents examined for viability.

Option A: Femoral hernia occurs in both males and females, but it is more common in multiparous females. Femoral hernia is more common on the right side because of the tamponading effect of the sigmoid colon on the left femoral canal. This effect is absent on the right side.

Option C: The incidence of strangulation in femoral hernias is high because of the narrowness of the neck of the sac and rigidity of the femoral ring.

Option D: Femoral vein is situated lateral to a femoral hernia (femoral canal).

questions.text: The false statement regarding the method shown in the image below is _____.

choices.text: It is a part of warm chain
It can be done by fathers also
Can not be carried out by hemodynamically unstable mothers

questions.solution:
The image shows kangaroo mother care. It can be carried out by hemodynamically unstable mothers who are on IV fluids, CPAP, or even ventilators.

Kangaroo mother care is part of warm chain transportation of babies, especially when incubator ambulances are not available for transportation of the baby.

Kangaroo discharge: early discharge from hospital has been shown to cause reduced rates of hospital-acquired infections.

Related Pearl: Baby-friendly hospital initiative (revised 2018)

Ten steps to successful breastfeeding (Revised 2018)

Critical management procedures

1  a. Comply fully with the International Code of Marketing of Breast-milk Substitutes and relevant World Health Assembly resolutions.

    b. Have a written infant feeding policy that is routinely communicated to staff and parents.

    c. Establish ongoing monitoring and data-management systems.

2. Ensure that staff has sufficient knowledge, competence, and skills to support breastfeeding.

Key clinical practices

3. Discuss the importance and management of breastfeeding with pregnant women and their families.

4. Facilitate immediate and uninterrupted skin-to-skin contact and support mothers to initiate breastfeeding as soon as possible after birth.

5. Support mothers to initiate and maintain breastfeeding and manage common difficulties.

6. Do not provide breastfed newborns any food or fluids other than breast milk, unless medically indicated.

7. Enable mothers and their infants to remain together and to practice rooming-in 24 hours a day.

8. Support mothers to recognize and respond to their infants’ cues for feeding.

9. Counsel mothers on the use and risks of feeding bottles, teats, and pacifiers.

10. Coordinate discharge so that parents and their infants have timely access to ongoing support and care.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old lady underwent copper-T IUCD insertion 2 months after the delivery of her baby. A few weeks after the procedure, she presented with pain abdomen. The tail of the IUCD is not visible. Her radiograph is shown in the image below. The most appropriate step in the management of this patient is?

IUCD: Intrauterine contraceptive device
questions.solution:
The given radiograph shows the IUCD outside the uterine cavity, most likely due to perforation. The most appropriate step in the management of this patient is the removal of the IUCD by laparotomy. 

The tail of the IUCD is not visible when the IUCD is misplaced. The reasons for misplaced IUCD include:

  • Enlargement of the uterus due to pregnancy
  • Curling of the threads inside the uterus
  • Perforation of the uterus
  • IUCD buried in the myometrium
  • Spontaneous expulsion

A plain X-ray or pelvic ultrasound is used in the localization of the IUCD when the IUCD threads cannot be visualized. In this patient, the misplaced IUCD is seen laterally displaced in the pelvic cavity. An abnormal location or abnormal shape of IUCD indicates likely perforation of the uterus. 

Perforation can occur either at the time of insertion (immediate traumatic perforation) or due to gradual erosion of the myometrium (secondary perforation). The risk factors for uterine perforation include:

  • Insertion by less experienced clinicians
  • Post-partum insertion (<6 months since delivery)
  • A higher number of previous abortions
  • Lower parity
  • Lactation

Management:

If the location of the IUCD is inside the uterine cavity, it can be removed using Shirodkar's hook (Option A), a curette, or a hysteroscope (option B) and ultrasound guidance.

In perforation of the uterus, a laparotomy is done as copper-T gets adhered to the omentum or gut and will be difficult to be removed using a laparoscope.

Other options:

Option A- Spontaneous expulsion is one of the reasons for misplaced IUCD. It is not a management approach. The factors that are associated with an increased risk of spontaneous expulsion of the IUCD are age <20 years and nulliparity. Expulsion tends to occur at the time of menstruation and is associated with cramping, bleeding, and vaginal discharge.

Here the IUCD has caused perforation of the uterus and is lodged outside the uterus, hence, spontaneous expulsion will not be possible.

questions.text: A 2 year old boy presenting with diarrhoea is irritable and drinks fluids eagerly when given. According to IMNCI, which of the following is the best suited treatment plan ?
questions.solution:
The clinical signs and symptoms of the above child signifies some dehydration. According to IMNCI, children with some dehydration or moderate dehydration should be treated with Plan B. 

In Plan B, fluid requirement (given orally) is calculated as :

  • Daily fluid requirement : Holliday Segar method
    Weight Quantity of fluids
    Upto 10 kg  100 ml/kg
    10-20 kg 1000 ml + 50ml/kg for every kg above 10 kg
    >20 kg 1500 ml + 20ml/kg for every kg above 20 kg
     
  • Deficit replacement or rehydration therapy - 75ml/kg of ORS over 4 hours
  • Maintenance therapy - Replace every stool with 10ml/kg of ORS after signs of dehydration disappear

Related Pearl: Treatment of dehydration based on severity

Plan A: For no dehydration or minimal dehydration. ORS is administered after each loose stool.

Age Amount 
<2 years 50–100 mL
2-10 years 100–200 mL
>10 years As much fluid as they want

Plan B: For moderate dehydration.

The amount of oral rehydration solution (ORS) to be given is 75 mL/kg body weight (wt × 75).

Plan C: Severe dehydration

Age First, give 30 mL/kg in Followed by 70 mL/kg in Total 100 mL/kg in
Infants (under 12 months) 1 hr 5 hrs  6 hrs
Older 30 min 2½ hrs  3 hrs

Note: Ringer lactate (ideal) or normal saline is used as intravenous fluids.

questions.text: Gerontology is the study of
questions.solution: Gerontology is the study of aging and its biological, cultural, social aspects.

questions.text: A 28-year-old coal miner presented with breathing difficulties. He reported that his symptoms get aggravated at work. His chest X-ray showed features of emphysema. On evaluation, he was found to have an α1-antitrypsin deficiency. Which pathological type of emphysema is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
The pathological type most likely to be present in this patient is pan-acinar emphysema. This type is commonly seen in patients with α1-antitrypsin deficiency.

Related Pearl: Types of emphysema

Emphysema is classified according to its anatomic distribution within the lobule.

Type Area involved Other features

Centriacinar (most common)
  • Central part of acinus (respiratory bronchiole)
  • Upper lobes of lung
  • Commonly seen in smokers
Panacinar
  • Entire acinus (respiratory bronchiole + alveoli)
  • Lower lobes of lung
  • Commonly seen in young non-smokers
  • Associated with α-1 antitrypsin deficiency
Paraseptal
  • Distal part of acinus (alveoli)
  • Subpleural region
  • Commonly seen in young adults 
  • Increased risk for spontaneous pneumothorax 
Irregular
  • Focal and irregular involvement of acinus
  • Areas of the lung near scar tissue 
  • Not usually seen in COPD

questions.text:
Identify the imaging modality given below.

USG- Ultrasonography
MRI- Magnetic resonance imaging
questions.solution:
The image shown in the question is the USG of the neck.

Sonographic examination of the neck shows the thyroid gland, muscles, blood vessels, bony structures or cartilages, and nerves. The thyroid of a healthy patient appears homogeneously echogenic with a uniform echotexture on USG. Lateral to the thyroid, the large blood vessels (the common carotid artery and more laterally, the internal jugular vein) can be identified. In the above image, hypoechoic areas are suggestive of the lumen of vessels seen in the neck i.e common carotid artery and internal jugular vein.

Neck ultrasonography is the preferred modality for routine radiographic evaluation of the thyroid gland, as it offers the most accurate visualization of thyroid nodular disease. It also allows for the concomitant performance of percutaneous fine-needle aspiration biopsy of thyroid lesions. 

Neck ultrasound can also be used to localize parathyroid disease. 

Other options:

Option B: Fluoroscopy is an imaging modality that allows real-time X-ray viewing of a patient with high resolution. During this procedure, radiologists usually use contrast material (dye) to highlight the area being examined.

Below image shows the fluoroscopy of neck.

 

Option C: The below image shows the X-ray appearance of neck in AP view.

 

Option D: Relative to the neck musculature, the thyroid is hyperintense on MRI images.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding CORADS?

CORADS- COVID-19 Reporting and Data System

choices.text: Pleural thickening is typical of COVID-19
Lobar consolidation is typical of COVID-19

questions.solution:
Among the given options, CORADS-5 is typical of COVID-19 is the true statement.

COVID-19 Reporting and Data System (CO-RADS) is a categorical assessment for pulmonary involvement of COVID-19 on chest CT.

CO-RADS Category Summary
CO-RADS 0 Scans are incomplete or of inferior quality
CO-RADS 1 Normal or non-infectious
CO-RADS 2 Typical features of other infections but not of COVID-19
CO-RADS 3  Features compatible with COVID-19 but also with other diseases
CO-RADS 4  Suspicious for COVID-19
CO-RADS 5  Typical for COVID-19
CO-RADS 6  Proven COVID-19 by positive RT-PCR test

 

CO-RADS categories:

  • CO-RADS 0: Not interpretable - Technically insufficient to assign a score: Scans are incomplete or of inferior quality.
  • CO-RADS 1: Very low level of suspicion for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19. Mild or severe emphysema, perifissural nodules, lung tumors, or fibrosis.
  • CO-RADS 2: Low level of suspicion for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19. Includes infectious etiology that is not compatible with COVID-19 such as bronchitis, bronchiolitis, bronchopneumonia, lobar pneumonia, abscess.
  • CO-RADS 3: Equivocal findings for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19. Findings overlap with other viral or infectious etiologies. Could include perihilar ground-glass, homogenous extensive ground-glass with or without sparing of secondary pulmonary lobules.
  • CO-RADS 4: High level of suspicion for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19. Findings are similar to CO-RADS 5 but are not present in the typical locations. Findings may also be superimposed on severe pre-existing pulmonary abnormalities.
  • CO-RADS 5 based on typical CT findings. It requires the presence of at least one confirmatory pattern (mentioned below).
  • CO-RADS 6: Proven COVID-19 by positive RT-PCR test.

CT features typical of pulmonary involvement in COVID-19 include:

  • Obligatory features
    • Ground glass opacities, with or without consolidation in areas close to the visceral pleural surface, including the fissures.
  • Confirmatory features
    • Ground glass regions
    • Crazy paving pattern
    • Organizing pneumonia compatible patterns 
    • Thickened vessels with parenchymal abnormalities

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding false labor pain.
questions.solution:
Bag of water formation occurs in true labor pain. All others are characteristic changes in false labor pain. 

Features True labour pains False labour pains
Cervical dilatation and effacement Present Absent
Pain Lower abdomen and back, radiating to thighs Lower abdomen only
Show Present Absent
Bag of water Formed Absent
Relief with enema or sedatives No Yes

False labor pain is more in primigravidae than in parous women. Generally, it appears 1 or 2 weeks prior to the onset of true labor pain in primigravidae and by a few days in multiparae.

It occurs due to stretching of the cervix and the lower uterine segment with consequent irritation of the neighboring ganglia.

Note:

Painless Braxton Hicks contractions with simultaneous hardening of the uterus occur throughout pregnancy. These contractions become more powerful, intermittent and are associated with pain terms as labor pain. They are most often felt in front of the abdomen or radiating towards the thighs.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented to the dermatology department with lesions over the skin as shown below.  On examination, the lesions were dry, scaly, and slightly shiny, with moderately diminished sensation. Which type of leprosy do these lesions indicate?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and image showing of moderately hypoesthetic annular plaques with punched-out lesions is suggestive of the borderline-borderline (BB) type of leprosy.

BB is the most immunologically unstable type of the borderline spectrum. Patients in BB will shift towards lepromatous or tuberculoid types quickly. 

Skin lesions in BB are in the form of infiltrated papules, plaques, nodules. The characteristic lesions of BB leprosy are annular plaques with well-demarcated, punched-out inner margins and a sloping outer margin. They appear as large plaques with islands of clinically normal skin within the center, giving rise to Swiss cheese appearance. 

 

Inverted saucer lesions are raised lesions with ill-defined borders that are mainly seen in borderline lepromatous (BL) type of leprosy lesions as shown below.

Pure neuritic leprosy (PNL) is a rare variant of leprosy. It is characterized by isolated involvement of peripheral nerve trunks in the absence of skin lesions.

Patients with PNL present with nerve thickening pain, tenderness, and sensory-motor impairment. Sensory neuropathies like loss of heat and pain sensitivities are more predominant in PNL. they most commonly present with mononeuritis.

questions.text: Most common cause of hypercalcemia in hospitalized patients:
questions.solution: Hyperparathyroidism and humoral hypercalcemia of malignancy (nonparathyroid cancer) are responsible for about 90% of all cases of hypercalcemia. Hyperparathyroidism is the most common cause of hypercalcemia detected by undirected methods such as routine screening, whereas cancer is the most common cause of hypercalcemia in hospitalized patients.

questions.text: Which of the following is a disorder of platelet adhesion?
questions.solution: Bernard Soulier syndrome is a disorder of platelet adhesion. It occurs due to an inherited defect in the GPIb-IX complex.
