questions.text: A 40-year-old male is overly conscious about perfection in all the work he does. He is very concerned about strictly following rules and becomes intolerant when the rules are not followed. Which of the following best describes this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario describes obsessive compulsive personality disorder. 

Obsessive compulsive /Anankastic personality disorder:

  • Obsessive-compulsive personality disorder is characterized by emotional constriction, orderliness, perseverance, stubbornness, and indecisiveness. The essential feature of the disorder is a pervasive pattern of perfectionism and inflexibility. It is ego-syntonic: behavior consistent with one’s own beliefs and attitudes (vs OCD which is ego dystonic and will cause distress to the patient).

Obsessive compulsive disorder:

  • It is characterised by the presence of obsessions and compulsive acts. In the given history, there are no obsessions or compulsions.

Related Pearl: Personality Disorders

Key features of Personality disorders

Prefers to be loner, detached, unemotional

questions.text: Which of the following symbol denotes identical twins in a pedigree chart?
questions.solution:
Option A  denotes monozygotic (identical) twins in a pedigree chart.

Related Pearl: Pedigree symbols

questions.text: During resuscitation, a patient received a 20% Intralipid injection. What could have been the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Patients who are unresponsive due to local anesthesia toxicity require 20% Intralipid injection during resuscitation. 

Accidental intravascular injection of local anesthetic like bupivacaine results in bupivacaine-induced cardiotoxicity.

Initial management includes immediate initiation of cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and defibrillation as per the advanced cardiac life support (ACLS) algorithm.

  • Following CPR, Intralipid therapy is initiated. A rapid bolus of Intralipid 20% IV (1.5 mL/kg) is administered without delay, followed by an infusion of 0.25 mL/kg/min. The infusion should be given continuously for at least 10 minutes after hemodynamic stability is achieved.
  • Intralipid decreases cardiac bupivacaine concentration by 11% within 3 minutes of administration, and cerebral bupivacaine concentration by 18% within 15 minutes.

Bupivacaine is a long-acting local anesthetic that is the most cardiotoxic among the local anesthetics. It depresses the rapid phase of depolarization in Purkinje fibers and ventricular muscle due to a decreased availability of fast sodium channels in cardiac membranes. This reduced rate of depolarization depresses myocardial contractility. Hence, bupivacaine is a potent cardio-depressant.

Note: Local anesthesia systemic toxicity (LAST) can also affect the central nervous system (CNS), which is more susceptible to local anesthetic action as compared to the cardiovascular system. Dizziness, tinnitus, and disorientation are the initial symptoms. Shivering, muscular twitching, and tremors follow. Tonic-clonic seizures occur. Finally, respiratory depression can lead to respiratory arrest.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman came to the OPD with a twin pregnancy at 10 weeks of gestation. She has a 3-year-old female child who was born at term and had 2 first trimester abortions previously. Which of the following is the correct representation of her obstetric score.
questions.solution:
The obstetric score is G4 P1 A2 L1. 

The obstetric score is used to summarise the past obstetric history as follows:

  • G - Gravidity, denoting the total number of pregnancies, including the present one
  • P - Parity, denoting the total number of pregnancies crossing the period of viability 
    • This includes both live births and stillbirths
    • The current pregnancy is not included
  • A - Abortus or the number of pregnancies that were lost for any reason, including induced abortions or miscarriages.
  • L - Living children

Multifetal pregnancies count as one for both gravida and para. A pregnant woman who delivers twins will be expressed as primipara.

The GTPAL system includes the following:

  • Gravida
  • Term (>37 weeks)
  • Preterm (20w - 36w 6d)
  • Abortions (<20 weeks)
  • Number of living children

Note: The period of viability is when the fetus is capable of independent existence. The WHO defines it to be 24 weeks while the Indian definition is 28 weeks.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding obesity?

choices.text: Naltrexone and Bupropion combination is FDA approved for obesity
Canagliflozin is contraindicated in obese diabetic patients
Laron syndrome patients have central obesity

questions.solution:
Canagliflozin causes moderate weight loss and is used in diabetic patients who are obese.

It is a Sodium-glucose transporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitor, having an insulin-independent mechanism that offers a considerable advantage of increasing urinary glucose excretion without inducing hypoglycemia and promoting weight loss due to loss of 300 to 400kcal/day.

Drugs used in obesity treatment:

  • Orlistat: Acts in the gastrointestinal system inhibiting intestinal lipase and hence reducing fat absorption.
  • Lorcaserin: Selective serotonin receptor agonist
  • Combination of Phentermine hydrochloride and Topiramate
  • Combination of Naltrexone and Bupropion Hydrochloride
  • Liraglutide: Injectable Glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonist

Option A: Naltrexone and Bupropion combination has been approved by FDA for the treatment of obesity.

Option C: Laron syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder that is mainly caused by mutations in the gene that encodes the GH receptor, resulting in GH resistance. This causes a severe deficiency in serum insulin-like growth factor – 1 (IGF- 1 ), resulting in short stature (dwarfism). Affected individuals have a prominent forehead, depressed nasal bridge, small mandible, and central obesity.

They may have recurrent hypoglycemic seizures. Partial resistance to GH may cause some cases of idiopathic short stature without features of Laron syndrome.

Option D: Hypothalamic damage causes obesity. Obesity also causes variable degrees of GH deficiency and male hypogonadotropic hypogonadism that are typically reversible with sufficient weight loss.

Surgery for obesity is indicated in patients with BMI more than 40 or BMI more than 35 with associated co-morbidities.

questions.text: What is 'mental retardation' now called according to the American Psychiatric Association in its revision of DSM 5?
questions.solution:
Mental retardation is now known as Intellectual Disability, according to the revised DSM 5, by the American Psychiatrist Association.

In the United States, the DSM serves as the principal authority for psychiatric diagnoses. The DSM-5 was published on May 18, 2013.

questions.text: You observed that the arms of an infant extend spontaneously when the senior resident tries to elicit the following reflex by holding the infant’s trunk and then suddenly lowering the infant as if he or she were falling. All the following options regarding this reflex is true except _______

choices.text: This reflex is  a prerequisite to walking
This reflex starts to appear by 7–8 months of age
This reflex disappears by 18 months of postnatal period

questions.solution:
The reflex being elicited in the given scenario is the Parachute reflex and this reflex remains throughout life.

  • The Parachute reflex is a primitive reflex that occurs at 7-8 months of age and it is fully developed by 10-11 months of the postnatal period.
  • It can be evoked by holding the infant’s trunk and then suddenly lowering the infant as if he or she were falling. The arms will spontaneously extend to break the infant’s fall.
  • This reflex is a prerequisite to walking.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was brought to the emergency room in a semi-conscious state after falling from his bike. He opens his eyes to painful stimuli and utters inappropriate words. On observation of his posture, he is seen to have a decorticate posture. His Glasgow coma scale (GCS) score would be:
questions.solution:
The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score based on the given clinical scenario is 8 (E2 V3 M3).

It is calculated as follows

  • E: Opening of the eyes to a painful stimulus - 2
  • V: Inappropriate words - 3
  • M: Decorticate posturing - 3

Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is used in the assessment of patients with a head injury.

Decorticate posture:

  • It is caused due to damage to the upper midbrain
  • The upper limbs are flexed, lower limbs are extended with toes pointed slightly inward, and head is extended.
  • Decorticate posturing is given a score of 3 in best motor response in Glasgow Coma Scale.

Decerebrate posture:

  • It is caused due to damage to the lower midbrain and upper pons
  • Here, lower extremities are extended with toes pointed inward and upper extremities extended with fingers flexed and forearms pronated. Neck and head are extended. 
  • Decerebrate posture has a score of 2 in best motor response in the Glasgow Coma Scale.

The below image shows decerebrate and decorticate posturing.

questions.text: ABCDE rule applies for:
questions.solution:
ABCDE rule applies to the diagnosis of Malignant Melanoma.

A: Asymmetry - lesions are irregular, or not symmetrical, in shape.

B: Border irregular - lesions usually have irregular borders that are ill-defined.

C: Color variegation - The presence of multiple colors (blue, black, brown, tan, etc.) or the uneven distribution of color.

D: Diameter >6 mm - lesions are often > 6 mm in diameter (approximately the size of a pencil eraser).

E: Evolution - There is a change in the size, shape, symptoms (such as itching or tenderness), surface (especially bleeding), or color of a mole.

questions.text: Where is the headquarters of the following organization located?
questions.solution:
The given image is the logo of the World Health Organization, WHO that has its headquarters located in Geneva, Switzerland.

WHO is a specialized, non-political health agency of the United Nations. It came into force on the 7th of April 1948. Its prime objective is the attainment by all people of the highest level of health. The structure of the WHO comprises the World Health Assembly, the Executive Board, and the Secretariat. 

 The responsibility of the WHO is in the following broad areas:

  1. Prevention and control of specific diseases
  2. Development of comprehensive health services
  3. Family health
  4. Environmental health
  5. Health statistics
  6. Biomedical research
  7. Health literature and information
  8. Co-operation with other international organizations

The headquarters of regional offices of WHO are:

  • The Southeast Asian regional office (SEARO) is in New Delhi, India
  • The African regional office is in Brazzaville, Republic of Congo.
  • The American regional office is in Washington D. C., USA.
  • The European regional head office is in Copenhagen, Denmark.
  • The Eastern Mediterranean regional office is in Alexandria, Egypt.
  • The Western Pacific regional office is in Manila, Philippines.

The headquarters of other important organizations are:

  • The headquarters of UNICEF and UNDP is in New York, USA.
  • The headquarters of the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) is in Rome, Italy.

Note: Other organizations that have headquarters in Geneva are the International Labor Organization (ILO) and the International Red Cross Society.

questions.text: Anti-retroviral therapy in HIV-infected individuals should be initiated at _______

choices.text: CD4 count <200 cells/ul and/or WHO clinical stage 2/3
CD4 count <350 cells/ul and/or WHO clinical stage 3/4
CD4 count <250 cells/ul and/or WHO clinical stage 4
Any CD4 count regardless of WHO clinical stage

questions.solution:
Antiretroviral therapy (ART) is recommended for all HIV patients, regardless of CD4 T lymphocyte cell count or clinical stage.

This is done to reduce the morbidity and mortality associated with HIV infection. A secondary goal of ART is to reduce the risk of HIV transmission.

Islatravir, the first nucleoside reverse transcriptase translocation inhibitor (NRTTI), along with Doravirine the recently approved non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI) may offer a potent and well-tolerated two-drug regimen for HIV maintenance therapy, according to a recent study.

Related Pearl: NACO ART Guidelines- 2021

ART regimen

First-line for:

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Dolutegravir
  • All PLHIV who are age >10 years and body weight >30 kg with HIV-1, HIV-2, HIV 1&2 co-infection who have not received any ART 
  • Those with HIV-TB and HIV hepatitis co-infections
  • Pregnant women, pregnant women presenting in active labour and breastfeeding women

Abacavir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz
  • All PLHIV with abnormal serum creatinine values 
  • All PLHIV with bodyweight less <30 kg

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz /Lopinavir /Ritonavir
  • Women of childbearing age group who do not wish to take Dolutegravir
  • All PLHIV who were on the previous recommended regime (Tenofovir+Lamivudine+Efavirenz) to be counselled to switch to new regime. Continue older regime if response is good
  • Women in child-bearing age group to be counselled about Dolutegravir with opt-out option before switching to new regime

*PLHIV: People living with HIV

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with itchy tense bullae over the limbs. The roof of the bullae collapsed after a few days. A clinical image is shown below, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of bullous pemphigoid.

Bullous pemphigoid is characterized by tense itchy bulla in the flexor areas and trunk which do not rupture easily. Elderly aged people are usually affected. It is a subepidermal immunobullous disorder, which occurs due to the production of autoantibodies (IgG) against BP180 (BPAG2) and BP 230 (BPAG1) antigens on hemidesmosomes. 

Mucosal membrane involvement is rare in this disease. Most of the lesions heal without a scar. Since these bullae are subepidermal, pressure over the lesions does not separate the epidermis from the dermis. (Nikolsky sign is negative).

Immunofluorescent microscopy will show the presence of subepidermal split and deposition of IgG antibodies at the dermo-epidermal junction. Histopathology will show the presence of subepidermal bullae with eosinophils.

It is mainly treated with corticosteroids. Other drugs used are azathioprine, dapsone, doxycycline, etc.

The above image (immunofluorescence microscopy) shows linear IgG deposits at the dermo-epidermal junction seen in the bullous pemphigoid.

Other options:

Option B: Pemphigus Vulgaris is an intraepidermal immunobullous disease. It occurs commonly between the 4th to 6th decade. They present with flaccid blisters. Firm pressure over the lesion separates the epidermis from the dermis. Nikolsky's sign is positive. Mucosal involvement will be seen in the form of buccal and palatal erosions

 

Option C: Dermatitis herpetiformis typically appears in the 4th decade, and the patients present with itching and rash, most typically over the extensor surfaces. The majority of the patient have symptoms related to gluten-sensitive enteropathies, like bloating, diarrhea, and other gastrointestinal complaints. Immunofluorescence microscopy will show the deposition of IgA antibodies in the papillary dermis in a granular or fibrillar pattern(as shown in the below image).

 

Option D: Linear Ig A dermatosis (Chronic bullous dermatosis of childhood) is an autoimmune blistering disease seen in infants and children. The disease can also be seen in adults and is known as Linear IgA disease of adults or IgA bullous pemphigoid. The blisters are arranged in an annular pattern commonly known as the crown of jewels appearance.

questions.text: The most common cause of HIV infection in a newborn is _________
questions.solution:
The most common cause of HIV infection in an infant is through perinatal transmission.

HIV transmission in an infant:

  • In utero (During pregnancy)
  • During delivery (Perinatal) Most common
  • After birth by breastfeeding - Least common.

Risk factors for vertical transmission:

  • High maternal viremia (most important)
  • Preterm delivery (<34 weeks)
  • Vitamin A deficiency
  • Prolonged rupture of membranes (>4 hours)
  • Low birth weight
  • Low maternal CD4 count

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is preferred for mild ulcerative colitis?
questions.solution:
The preferred drug for mild ulcerative colitis (UC) is 5-ASA agents (5-Aminosalicylic acid). 

5-ASA acts by inhibiting cytokines, TNFα, nuclear transcription factor NFκB, and prostaglandin synthesis leading to anti-inflammatory effect. 5-ASA is useful in inducing and maintaining remission in mild and moderate UC ONLY.

Severe UC requires glucocorticoids like budesonide.

They may have a limited role in inducing remission in Crohn's disease (CD). Therefore, they are used along with glucocorticoids. 

6-Mercaptopurine (6MP) and azathioprine are used as maintenance therapy in both UC and CD.

questions.text: A teenager presented with complaints of excessive growth of coarse hair on her jawline and upper lip. Which of the following is the most common cause for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of excessive growth of coarse hair is suggestive of hirsutism. The most common cause for hirsutism in female patients is polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS).

Hirsutism is defined as excessive growth of androgen-dependent sexual hair or male distribution of hair in female patients. PCOS accounts for 70-80% of the cases of hirsutism, which typically begins in late adolescence or the early 20s.

Idiopathic hirsutism is the second most frequent cause. The most common rapid onset of hirsutism in young females is a testosterone-producing tumour like granulosa cell or Sertoli-Leydig cell tumours.

Other less common causes of hirsutism include:

  • Late-onset congenital adrenal hyperplasia
  • Tumours of the ovary and adrenal gland
  • Cushing’s syndrome
  • Drug-induced

Virilisation: Characterized by more extensive androgen-induced changes than hirsutism alone. It has the following features:

  • Acne
  • Increased oily skin
  • Temporal balding
  • Clitoromegaly
  • Deepening of the voice
  • Development of male muscular pattern and body habitus
  • Atrophy of breasts

Hypertrichosis: Excessive growth of non-sexual hair.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient was intubated for surgery by a final-year resident. Which of the following is the best method to confirm the position of the endotracheal tube?
questions.solution:
The best method to confirm the position of the endotracheal tube is the end-tidal CO2 concentration assessed by capnography. 

Capnography is a non-invasive method of measurement and graphical display of partial pressure of carbon dioxide (CO2) in exhaled breath or the end-tidal CO2. Capnograph is the device used for measurement and capnogram is the CO2 waveform that is displayed. It is the most reliable indicator of endotracheal tube placement.

The proper placement of the endotracheal tube is indicated by a normal CO2 waveform for at least three breaths.

Other signs to confirm proper endotracheal intubation are symmetrical chest rise, presence of equal bilateral breath sounds, absent breath sounds over the epigastrium, visible condensation in the ETT, large exhaled tidal volume and appropriate compliance of the reservoir bag during manual ventilation.

Absent CO2 waveform tracing despite correct ETT intubation is seen in the following conditions:

  • Severe bronchospasm,
  • Equipment malfunction,
  • Cardiac arrest, or hemodynamic collapse 

Clinical relevance:

  • Capnography does not differentiate endotracheal from endobronchial intubation. Signs of endobronchial intubation include increased peak expiratory pressure, hypoxemia, increased airway pressures, asymmetric chest expansion and the absence of breath sounds over one lung, generally the left.  
  • In esophageal intubation, the capnograph can initially detect some CO2 in the stomach from swallowing expired air. But after a few breaths, this CO2  will be washed out and ETCO2 will become zero. 
  • The most sensitive and earliest indicator of malignant hyperthermia is a persistent increase in ETCO2.

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

questions.text: You are performing Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP). A male attendant claiming himself to be the expecting father shows you his identity proof. He demands you to reveal the identity of the patient and pressurizes to stop the procedure. How will you handle the situation?

choices.text: Reveal the identity, discontinue the medical termination of pregnancy (MTP)
Refrain revealing the identity, discontinue the medical termination of pregnancy (MTP)
Reveal the identity, continue the medical termination of pregnancy (MTP)
Refrain revealing the identity, continue the medical termination of pregnancy (MTP)

questions.solution:
Refrain revealing the identity, continue the medical termination of pregnancy in such like situations.

The full confidentiality of the female has to be ensured by the doctor. A register for recording the details of medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) must be kept for at least 5 years. The patient's name must not be entered, only the reference number is used.

Unlawful disclosure of a patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment ± fine. Only the patient's consent is required for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) and her male partner's consent is not required. Consent of parent/guardian is needed if the age of the patient is <18 yrs or if the patient is mentally ill.

questions.text: A child was brought to the clinic for evaluation of recurrent UTI. Ultrasound revealed a dilated renal pelvis. Intravenous urogram done is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and intravenous urogram showing a "drooping lily" sign point to a diagnosis of a duplex kidney. 

It refers to the presence of duplicated ureters or collecting systems. This is due to the incomplete fusion of the upper and lower pole of the kidney. Duplex kidneys have two separate pelvicalyceal systems draining single renal parenchyma.

The lower pole ureter is normally inserted into the bladder. However, the upper pole ureter has an ectopic insertion. It crosses the lower pole ureter to open inferior and medial to the normal site of insertion (Weigert–Meyer rule). This results in reflux and incontinence.

Option B: In retrocaval ureter, the IVC presses on the right ureter as it lies behind the IVC. Intravenous urogram shows reversed ‘J’/ fish hook ureter.

questions.text: A 20 yr old male was brought to casualty in unconscious state after a head injury.What is the name of the sign seen in this image?
questions.solution:
The image is of battle sign i.e. a skull base fracture associated with bruising over mastoid process.

Middle Cranial Fossa Fracture is associated with:

  • CSF otorrhea or rhinorrhea
  • Hemotympanum
  • Ossicular disruption
  • Battle sign: Bruising behind the ear
  • 7th and 8th cranial nerve palsies

Anterior Cranial Fossa Fracture is associated with:

  • Subconjunctival hematoma
  • CSF rhinorrhea
  • Carotico-cavernous fistula
  • Periorbital hematoma or “Raccoon eyes”

 

Related Pearl: Signs of base of skull fracture

Signs of Base of Skull Fracture

  • Bilateral periorbital haematoma (raccoon eyes)
  • Battle’s sign (bruising over mastoid)
  • CSF rhinorrhoea or otorrhoea
  • Haemotympanum or bleeding from ear

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of congenital syphilis?
questions.solution:
Puhl lesion is not a feature of congenital syphilis. Other three options form the Hutchinsons triad which is seen in congenital syphilis.

Hutchinsons triad refers to

  • Interstitial keratitis
  • 8th nerve deafness
  • Hutchinson incisors

It is seen in late congenital syphilis.

Other option:

 Puhl lesion-Supraclavicular lesion is chronic/secondary tuberculosis.

Related Pearl: Syphilis - Diagnostic Serology

Nontreponemal tests (VDRL, RPR)

VDRL- Venereal disease Research Laboratory test

RPR- Rapid Plasma Reagin test

  • Quantitative tests(titres)
  • Reagin antibody tests; based on cardiolipin antigen
  • VDRL can be used to test CSF whereas RPR cannot be used
  • RPR does not require preheating of serum unlike VDRL
  • VDRL requires light microscope for interpretation whereas RPR can be read macroscopically
  • Decrease in titers confirms treatment
  • Sensitivity of RPR(86%)>VDRL(76%) in primary syphilis

Treponemal Tests

FTA-ABS- Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption test

TPI-Treponema pallidum immobilization test

TPPA-Treponema pallidum particle agglutination assay

TPHA-Treponema pallidum haemagglutination test

EIA-Enzyme-linked ImmunoAssay

  • Detect antibody to treponemal antigens
  • Qualitative tests
  • Greater sensitivity in early infection
  • Positive even after treatment hence cannot be used to detect reinfection.
  • First test to be positive: FTA-ABS
  • Most specific: TPHA,TPPA, EIA

questions.text: The nanny of a 3-year-old boy brings the child to the ER after he had accidentally ingested button batteries from the mobile phone toy that he was playing with. What would be the next best step in the management of this child?

choices.text: Observation and follow up in 24 hours
Observation until the foreign body passes out in faeces

questions.solution:
Button batteries and sharp objects in the oesophagus and foreign bodies associated with respiratory symptoms all mandate urgent endoscopic removal.

Button batteries, in particular, are very dangerous foreign bodies, which must be expediently removed because they can cause:

  • Mucosal injury in 1-hour contact time
  • Involve all layers of the oesophagus in 4 hours

Injury is thought to be secondary to electrochemical burns from electrical discharge. Chemical burns from electrolyte alkali leakage and pressure necrosis also may contribute to mucosal injury.

Asymptomatic blunt objects and coins lodged in the oesophagus can be observed for up to 24 hr in anticipation of passage into the stomach.

questions.text: Ms. Sheela came to the clinic with a history of a breast lump for the past 6 months. The mammogram showed the presence of microcalcifications. Histopathology of the lump showed the presence of the comedo growth pattern. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is ductal carcinoma in situ.

Comedo subtype refers to the presence of necrosis. It implies that the tumor cells are growing rapidly and the blood vessel is not able to supply all the malignant cells. On the contrary, non-comedo subtype implies that the tumor is growing slowly and the blood vessel is able to supply all the cells. Therefore, the comedo subtypes are of high-grade DCIS.

questions.text: You have been invited to a child's birthday party. On reaching his home, you notice him ride a tricycle to the stairs and then get off, climb the stairs with alternate feet to reach his room. He has built a tower of 9 blocks in his room and is able to copy a circle using the glitter pens you gifted him. What is the likely age that these milestones correspond to?
questions.solution:
These milestones correspond to an age of 3 years.

The milestones attained by a child at age 3 are:

  • Gross motor development: Can ride a tricycle and walk up the stairs with alternate feet
  • Fine motor development: Can build a tower of 9 blocks and can copy a circle
  • Social and adaptive: Shares toys, begins to count, can identify 1-2 colours 
  • Language: Continually asks questions, knows full name

questions.text: A 40-year-old man came with complaints of chronic constipation,  blood-streaked stools, and pain during defecation for 2 months. On examination, a sentinel tag was noted at the anal orifice. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is an anal fissure.

An anal fissure is a liner ulcer usually found in the midline, distal to the dentate line. It is one of the most common causes of anal pain and bleeding.

They typically start with a tear in the anoderm within the distal half of the anal canal which then triggers cycles of recurring anal pain and bleeding, which lead to the development of a chronic anal fissure. The exposed internal sphincter muscle within the bed of the fissure frequently spasms, which not only contributes to severe pain but also can restrict blood flow to the fissure, preventing its healing. Ischemia may contribute to the development of an anal fissure. The anoderm at the posterior midline, the most common location of primary fissures, receives less than one-half of blood flow compared with other quadrants of the anal canal.

The vast majority of anal fissures are located in the posterior midline of the anal canal.

Lateral internal sphincterotomy is the operation of choice for chronic fissures.

 

Other options:

Option A: Pilonidal sinus is usually seen in the midline of the sacrococcygeal region of young men with a lot of body hair. This presence of hair in the gluteal cleft seems to play a central role in the pathogenesis of this disease and is consistent with the observation that pilonidal disease rarely occurs in those with less body hair. Diagnosis is generally a clinical one; patients may present with chronic inflammation or a sinus with persistent drainage. Acutely, there may be an abscess present

Option C: Haemorrhoids when uncomplicated typically do not cause pain. Only a thrombosed external haemorrhoid or occurrence of an incarcerated/strangulated internal haemorrhoid can cause severe anorectal pain and/or bleeding. Those conditions can usually be distinguished from anal fissure by their appearance on examination

Option D: Anal fistula is observed as a draining skin punctum located anywhere in the circumference of the anal margin. Probing the skin punctum reveals a track that extends from the perianal skin toward the anorectum. The drainage from the fistula tract can be purulent, and inadequate drainage can result in an associated abscess formation. An anal fissure does not have such a track

questions.text: Not true regarding the condition in the given image?

choices.text: Incomplete cyst wall removal causes recurrence
A punctum may not always be visible

questions.solution:
The image shows an infected sebaceous cyst(epidermoid cyst) as evident by the inflammation of the swelling. Malignancies in epidermoid cysts are very rare. 

Other options: 

Incomplete removal of the cyst wall is indeed a frequent cause of recurrence

Punctum is not always clinically visible as it can be buried

Injection of triamcinolone Perilesionally aids faster resolution & clearing of infection. But this does not cause the eradication of cyst 

 

The most common site of a Sebaceous cyst is postauricular sulcus or below and behind the ear lobule. They are fixed to the skin and usually have a central punctum.

Treatment depends on the clinical state of the cyst. When inflamed or infected, they should be incised and drained initially, total surgical excision should be done once the inflammation has subsided.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man complains of abdominal pain and blood stained stools. The barium study of his intestines shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the radiological images are suggestive of intussusception.

In intussusception the occluding mass prolapsing into the lumen has been termed the coiled spring appearance (barium in the lumen of the intussusceptum and in the intraluminal space). In adults, it develops due to a tumor of the bowel.

The intussusception appears as a sausage shaped mass in longitudinal plane or a target mass in transverse plane  on CT and USG. 

Ultrasound signs include:

  • Target sign (also known as the doughnut sign)
  • Pseudokidney sign
  • Crescent in a doughnut sign.

Other options: Volvulus presents with constipation, abdominal bloating, nausea and/or vomiting. It shows coffee bean sign.

questions.text:
Based on the new update to the MELD score i.e. MELD 3.0, an elderly woman with end-stage liver disease now has a higher score and is deemed eligible for a liver transplant. Which of the following is a new component that has been added to the MELD 3.0 scoring system?

MELD- model for end-stage liver disease
questions.solution:
Female gender is one of the new components that has been added to the MELD 3.0 scoring system.

According to the previous model, MELDNa, the components of the scoring system were serum creatinine, bilirubin, sodium(Options A, B, and C), and the INR (international normalized ratio). The updated MELD 3.0 scoring system has added two additional components- serum albumin and female gender. 

According to research published in 2021, the addition of these two components and certain adjustments made in the other components has led to a better scoring system. MELD 3.0 now allows for a more accurate prediction of mortality than the previous MELDNa scoring system. An important improvement is that it addresses factors that can affect wait-list outcomes such as sex disparity. MELD 3.0 is able to correctly reclassify almost 9% of patients to a higher MELD tier, giving them a much better chance of transplantation, particularly in women. 

It is estimated that almost 20 waitlist deaths can be reduced per year with the new MELD 3.0 scoring system.

questions.text: A person fell backwards and landed on the dorsal part of one of his elbows. He complains of severe pain behind the elbow. His X-ray is given below. Which of the following is a treatment method in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows a displaced transverse fracture of the olecranon. Tension band wiring is one of the management methods in this case. 

The Mayo classification divides olecranon fractures into three groups based on fracture displacement and elbow stability. Each group is further subdivided into comminuted (A) or noncomminuted (B). 

  • Type I (undisplaced)
  • Type II (displaced but stable)
  • Type III (unstable)

Management:

Type I can be managed nonoperatively, while Type II and III generally require surgery. 

  • Simple olecranon fractures without comminution or instability are managed with tension-band wiring, plate fixation, or an intramedullary rod.
  • Comminuted fractures and fractures with elbow instability are managed with plate fixation.
  • In osteoporotic patients when there is significant comminution, excision of the olecranon with triceps advancement is done.

questions.text: A 67-year-old patient with end-stage renal disease is tested positive for COVID-19. Which anticoagulation agent would you recommended for him?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of COVID-19 in a patient with end-stage renal disease. Unfractionated heparin is recommended for use in such patients.

Prophylactic anticoagulation is used in the management of moderate and severe COVID cases. A prophylactic dose of low molecular weight heparin or unfractionated heparin is used to prevent thromboembolism. In a COVID patient with end-stage renal disease, unfractionated heparin is the preferred agent.

questions.text: Mr.Dheeraj has been diagnosed with alcoholic hepatitis. All of the following are indications for prednisolone except  _______

choices.text: Active GI bleeding requiring blood transfusions

questions.solution:
Active GI bleeding is not an indication of glucocorticoid therapy. 

Indications for glucocorticoid therapy include:

  • Discriminant Function (DF) ≥ 32
  • Model for End-stage Liver Disease (MELD) ≥ 21
  • Presence of hepatic encephalopathy

Glucocorticoid therapy is avoided in (Exclusion criteria):

  • Active GI bleeding requiring blood transfusions
  • Active infection requiring antibiotic treatment
  • Preexisting chronic renal disease with a serum creatinine level greater than 2 mg/dL
  • Pancreatitis 
  • Obvious contraindications to glucocorticoid therapy

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the primary health center for a routine medical check-up. What is the dosage of iron and folic acid supplementation for this patient under the Anemia Mukth Bharath initiative?

choices.text: 20 mg elemental iron + 100 mcg folic acid bi-weekly
45 mg elemental iron + 400 mcg folic acid weekly
60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid weekly
60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid daily

questions.solution:
According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat initiative, children between 5-9 years of age need to take 45 mg elemental iron + 400 mcg folic acid tablets once a week. These tablets are sugar-coated, and pink in color.

Anemia Mukt Bharat 2018 scheme: 

This is an initiative aims to strengthen the existing mechanisms and foster newer strategies for tackling anemia. It focuses on six target beneficiary groups, through six interventions and six institutional mechanisms to achieve their target by 2022.

Interventions:

  • Prophylactic iron and folic acid supplementation
  • Deworming
  • Intensified year-round Behaviour Change Communication Campaign (Solid Body, Smart Mind) including ensuring delayed cord clamping in newborns
  • Testing of anemia using digital methods and point of care treatment
  • Mandatory provision of Iron and Folic Acid fortified foods in government-funded health programs
  • Addressing non-nutritional causes of anemia in endemic pockets, with a special focus on malaria, hemoglobinopathies, and fluorosis

Beneficiaries:

  • Children, 6-59 months of age
  • Children, 5-9 years of age
  • Adolescent girls and boys, 10-19 years of age
  • Women of reproductive age, 20-49 years of age
  • Pregnant women
  • Lactating mothers, 0-6 months

questions.text: A woman who underwent dilation and curettage following a missed abortion now presents with amenorrhoea. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Hysterosalpingography shows the findings seen in the image below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history along with the moth-eaten appearance on hysterosalpingography suggests a diagnosis of Asherman syndrome.

In Asherman syndrome, oligomenorrhoea, amenorrhoea, dysmenorrhoea, abortion and infertility are seen with uterine synechiae.

The synechiae are caused by the following factors:

  • Vigorous curettage following postpartum haemorrhage or abortion
  • Tubercular endometritis
  • Uterine infections with or without intra-uterine device

Treatment involves hysteroscopic lysis of the adhesions

questions.text: Diagnostic laparoscopy was performed on a patient who presented with infertility. During the procedure, the surgeon notices powder burn spots over the pelvic viscera. The diagnosis would be?
questions.solution:
Powder burn spots over pelvic viscera is seen in pelvic endometriosis. 

Typically, there are small black dots, the so-called powder burns/gunshot appearance seen on the serosal surfaces of the peritoneum. They are black, dark brown, or bluish nodules or can be small cysts containing old hemorrhage surrounded by a variable degree of fibrosis.

Other subtle appearances of endometriosis are red flame-shaped areas, red polypoid areas, yellow-brown patches, white peritoneal plaques or scarring, peritoneal defects (known as Allen Masters Syndrome), and subovarian adhesions. These lesions are thought to be more active than the powder burn areas.

Other pathology in Endometriosis:

  • Peritoneal cavity: contains yellowish-brown fluid which has prostaglandin responsible for the pain of endometriosis.
  • Ovary: Chocolate cyst (True cyst with columnar epithelium lining)

Powder burn appearance:

questions.text: The most common renal lesion in hepatitis C infection is
questions.solution:
The most common renal lesion in hepatitis C infection is cryoglobulinemic glomerulonephritis, followed by membranous glomerulonephritis, and type I membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

Cryoglobulins are the immunoglobulins that precipitate when the temperature is less than 37°C. Cryoglobulinemia means the presence of cryoglobulins in the serum. Deposition of these immune complexes leads to cutaneous vasculitis, arthritis, peripheral neuropathy, and glomerulonephritis. 

Causes of cryoglobulinemic vasculitis:

  • Idiopathic
  • Hepatitis C
  • Multiple myeloma
  • Connective tissue disorders
  • Liver diseases

The presence of cryoprecipitate containing oligoclonal/polyclonal immunoglobulins in the absence of underlying disease was called essential mixed cryoglobulinemia. The majority of these cases have an underlying hepatitis C infection.

Laboratory investigations will show the presence of circulating cryoprecipitates, positive for rheumatoid factor, and hypocomplementemia. They have to be tested for hepatitis C antibodies and hepatitis C RNA.

questions.text: Precocious puberty  is defined by the onset of secondary sexual characteristics before the age of_________.

choices.text: 9 years in girls and 8 years in boys
7 years in girls and 8 years in boys
8 years in girls and 9 years in boys
9 years in girls and 10 years in boys

questions.solution:
Precocious puberty is defined as the onset of secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 8 years in girls and 9 years in boys.

Depending on the primary source of hormonal production, precocious puberty can be classified in the following manner:

Central Precocious Puberty

(Gonadotropin-dependent puberty)

Peripheral Precocious Puberty

(Gonadotropin independent)

Due to the excess secretion of gonadotropins (FSH and LH) from pituitary

Due to excess secretion of testosterone or estrogen from the gondas/adrenals.

Always isosexual (appearance of phenotypically appropriate secondary sexual characteristics before age 8 years in girls and before 9 years in boys).

Can be isosexual or heterosexual (appearance of secondary sex characters of the opposite sex).

Girls 

  • Idiopathic (most common)

Boys

  • CNS pathology (most common)

Girls 

  • Estrogenic ovarian cysts (isosexual)
  • Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) (testosterone increases; heterosexual)

Boys

  • CAH (isosexual; most common)

Note:

Central Precocious Puberty >> Peripheral Precocious Puberty

questions.text: A 33-year-old pregnant woman at 20 weeks of gestation has the following finding on USG. Identify the defect.
questions.solution:
The given ultrasound image shows a midline anterior abdominal wall defect through which abdominal contents have herniated (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac. This is typical of omphalocele.

Omphalocele is a midline anterior abdominal wall defect through which the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel may herniate. The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac. These are due to the persistence of physiological herniation of the gut or as a part of the OEIS complex (omphalocele, exstrophy, imperforate anus, and spinal abnormality) and cloacal exstrophy. The elephant’s trunk sign on ultrasound, due to the prolapsed terminal ileum is said to be pathognomonic for cloacal exstrophy of the OEIS complex. 

 The image below shows a patient with cloacal exstrophy showing the elephant trunk sign representing the intussuscepted ileum.

 

The image below shows omphalocele.

 

The image below shows gastroschisis (a close differential diagnosis for omphalocele).

 

Option A: Anencephaly results from incomplete closure of the neural tube. It is one of the earliest detectable congenital defects that can be detected as early as 10 to 11 weeks of gestation. Screening can also be done by serum estimation of maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP). The following are the radiological signs seen in anencephaly - 

 Frog eye sign - Absence of cranial calvaria, prominent orbits thereby resembling the face of a frog. 

 

 

Shower cap sign - The absence of the cranium could lead to the protrusion of a disorganized mass of brain tissue. This resembles a shower cap giving rise to a characteristic triangular facial appearance.

 

Option C: Cystic hygroma is a congenital multiloculated lymphatic lesion that is classically found in the left posterior triangle of the neck. It occurs as a result of sequestration or obstruction of developing lymph vessels. It must be carefully differentiated from nuchal translucency (NT) as both may appear similar. This defect can be picked up in a first-trimester ultrasound. 

 The image below shows a newborn with cystic hygroma on the right side of the neck.

 

The image below shows cystic hygroma of the neck in the fetus.

 

Option D: Encephalocele is caused due to defects in the skull through which the meninges and/or neural tissue herniate. The squamous part of the occipital bone is the most frequently affected bone. In meningoencephalocele or occult spina bifida with Chiari malformations, the scalloping of the frontal bones is observed in the ultrasound as the lemon sign while anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa forms the banana sign. 

 The image shows a newborn with encephalocele. 

 

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign on USG as seen below.

 

The scalloping of the frontal bones is observed in the ultrasound as the lemon sign as seen below.

questions.text: A post-coital test was done in a couple who presented with an inability to conceive despite staying together for 4 years and having unprotected intercourse. Which of the following conditions cannot be detected by this test?
questions.solution:
The post-coital test can not detect a fallopian tube block. It can evaluate the following conditions:

  • Sperm count
  • Sperm morphology
  • Ferning during the estrogenic effect
  • Ovulation
  • The ability of the cervical mucous to allow sperm penetration
  • Detection of anti-sperm antibodies in the cervical mucous

In the post-coital test, the couple is advised to have intercourse early in the morning close to the ovulation phase. The woman is asked to visit the clinic within 2 hours of having intercourse. The mucus is aspirated from the cervical canal and spread over a glass slide. Another smear made from the posterior fornix serves as a control.

On microscopy, 10–50 motile sperms are normally seen per high-power field. The cervical mucus is also examined for its quantity and viscosity. The post-coital test is useless in the presence of cervical infection.

An immunological factor causing infertility is encountered in around 5% of infertile couples.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect regarding pheochromocytoma?

choices.text: Surgical  excision is the definitive  treatment
Propranolol is given initially to manage hypertension
Can present as hypertension alone,  sometimes with vomiting and  pain abdomen

questions.solution:
Alpha-blockers like phenoxybenzamine are given initially to manage hypertension in pheochromocytoma. Beta-blockers such as propranolol are given only after adequate alpha blockade is achieved.

Pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine secreting tumor. High levels of circulating catecholamines stimulate the alpha receptors on the blood vessels and cause vasoconstriction, resulting in hypertension. If β-blockers are given initially, it will lead to unopposed α-stimulant action of catecholamines leading to hypertensive crisis. This is the rationale behind prescribing alpha-blockers initially and then followed by β-blockers in pheochromocytoma.

 

Pheochromocytoma:

Pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine secreting tumor derived from the chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla.

It can be sporadical or hereditary. Hereditary pheochromocytoma occurs in association with syndromes such as MEN 2 (Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2), familial paraganglioma syndrome, Von Hippel Lindau (VHL) syndrome, and neurofibromatosis (NF) type 1.

Clinical features:

It most commonly presents as a classic triad of intermittent headache, palpitation, and profuse sweating along with hypertension. The patient can also present with anxiety, panic attacks, nausea, abdominal pain, weight loss, and weakness.

Symptoms may be precipitated by surgery, pregnancy, position changes, exercise, and medications such as metoclopramide and tricyclic antidepressants.

Investigations:

  1. Biochemical screening test - measurement of urinary and plasma levels of catecholamines and metanephrines. 
  2. MRI is the investigation of choice for localizing the tumor. It is preferred over a CT scan as the contrast used in CT scans can precipitate paroxysms.
  3. Other imaging modalities like MIBG scintigraphy, DOPA- or FDG- PET scan are used in identifying the primary tumor as well as the extra-adrenal tumors and metastases.

Treatment:

Surgical resection of the tumor is the definitive treatment for pheochromocytoma.

Preoperatively, hypertension is managed initially with alpha-blockers followed by beta-blockers.

Postoperatively, lifelong yearly follow-up should be done.

questions.text: The baby is in which station?
questions.solution:
The head of the fetus it at the level of ischial spines. So it is in station 0.

  • The fetal station, that is the level of the presenting fetal part in the birth canal, is described in relation to the ischial spines. These spines lie halfway between the pelvic inlet and the pelvic outlet. When the lowermost portion of the presenting fetal part is at the level of the ischial spines, it is designated to be in zero station.
  • As the presenting fetal part descends from the inlet toward the ischial spines the designation is -5,-4, -3,-2,-1 then 0 station.
  • Below the spines, the presenting part passes +1,+2,+3,+4,+5 stations. Station +5 corresponds to the fetal head is visible at the level of introitus.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true regarding Brodie abscess?

choices.text: It a localized variant of chronic osteomyelitis
Lytic lesion with dense sclerotic rim

questions.solution:
Brodie’s abscess is a localized variant of subacute osteomyelitis with a milder presentation which appears as a lytic lesion with a dense sclerotic rim on radiograph.

It is associated with little or no periosteal reaction. It most commonly involves the metaphysis of the proximal tibia and distal femur. The patient presents with intermittent pain and tenderness in the affected area.

 A biopsy is often needed to confirm the diagnosis. It is managed by antibiotics and curettage.

 

 

The above x-ray shows the dense sclerotic rim and minimal periosteal reaction in the upper end of the tibia.

Differential diagnosis of Brodie abscess :

 Brodie abscess can be mistaken for many neoplasms on plain radiographs and all of such conditions may present with a history of swelling and pain. However, the differentiating features of each of the conditions are as follows:

Condition Age group Radiographic findings
Brodie's abscess

Children, adolescents

 Lytic lesion with dense sclerotic rim, minimal periosteal reaction
Osteosarcoma Children, adolescents and seventh decade Periosteal reaction leading to sunray appearance and Codman triangle
Osteoclastoma 20-40 years Lytic lesion with thin sclerotic rim, minimal periosteal reaction
Ewing's sarcoma 10-20 years Periosteal reaction leading to onion peel appearance

questions.text: Personal monitoring of radiation is done by:
questions.solution:
Personal monitoring of radiation is done by TLD badge.

TLD badge (Thermoluminescent dosimeter) is made up of Lithium fluoride or dysprosium.

The badge should be positioned according to local or national practices, and the individuals are advised to wear badges at either the waist or the collar level or to wear them either under the lead apron or outside the lead apron.

  • Surgery is the treatment of choice for Hirschsprung disease.

  • Definitive surgeries for Hirschsprung disease are as follows:
    • Swenson

questions.text: Which of the following is the Miami criteria for intraoperative parathyroid hormone (PTH) measurement?
questions.solution:
A drop in the level of PTH to less than half the maximum value (corresponding to the preoperative levels)  at 10 min post-resection is the Miami criteria.

This criterion is used to determine the adequacy of resection of the parathyroid gland which is done in a case of primary hyperparathyroidism due to adenoma.

questions.text: The most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas is
questions.solution:
The most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas is an insulinoma (4 per million).

The investigation of choice for insulinoma is the determination of  72-hour fasting glucose and serum insulin levels.

Medical management includes:

  • Frequent carbohydrate-rich meals
  • Octreotide

Surgical management is the definitive treatment. It includes enucleation and pancreatectomy. 

Other options:

Option A: Gastrinoma has an incidence of 0.5 to 4 in a million.

Options B & D: Somatostatinoma and VIPoma are much rarer than gastrinoma.

Related Pearl: Pancreatic Endocrine Neoplasms

Endocrine neoplasm

Syndrome

Glucagonoma

Mild diabetes mellitus, a characteristic skin rash (necrolytic migratory erythema), and anemia

Insulinoma

Clinically significant hypoglycemia

Gastrinoma

Peptic ulceration often unresponsive to therapy and in unusual locations such as the jejunum

Somatostatinoma

Diabetes mellitus, cholelithiasis, steatorrhea, and hypochlorhydria

VIPoma

Watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria, or WDHA syndrome

Pancreatic polypeptide-secreting endocrine tumors

Present as mass lesions as even high plasma levels of this hormone fail to cause symptoms
  • Islet hyperplasia (previously known as nesidioblastosis) is seen in maternal diabetes, Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome , and rare mutations in the β-cell K+-channel protein or sulfonylurea receptor.
  • In maternal diabetes, the fetal islets respond to hyperglycemia by increasing their size and number. In the postnatal period, these hyperactive islets may be responsible for serious episodes of hypoglycemia.

Related Pearl: Whipple's Triad

Whipple’s triad describes the clinical symptoms of insulinoma.

  • Symptoms of hypoglycemia after fasting or exercise
  • Plasma glucose levels <2.8 mmol/L or 50 mg/dL.
  • Relief of symptoms after intravenous administration of glucose.

questions.text: DDT is a ________
questions.solution:
• DDT is a contact poison of the organochlorine compound type.

Related Pearl: Insecticides

Contact poisons

  • Natural: Pyrethrum, rotenone, derris, nicotine, mineral oils
  • Synthetic:
    • Organo-chlorine compounds: DDT, methoxychlor, HCH, lindane, chlordane, heptachlor, dieldrin, aldrin, toxaphene, kepone, mirex.
    • Repellants: Benzyl benzoate, indalone, meta-diethyltoluamide, dimethyl phthalate, ethyl hexanediol.
    • Organo-phosphorus compounds: Chlorthion (aryl), diazinon (aryl), demethoate, malathion (alkyl), fenthion, parathion (aryl), trichlorfon (alkyl), runnel, abale, naled, chlorpyrifos, fenitrothion, dicapthon.
    • Carbamates: Carbaryl, dimetilan, propoxur, pyrolan.
    • Synthetic pyrethroids: Prothrin, resmethrin, bioresmethrin, permethrin, proparthin, tetramethrin
  • Stomach poisons: Paris green, sodium fluoride.
  • Fumigants: Hydrogen cyanide, methyl bromide, sulphur dioxide, carbon disulphide.
Specific Insecticides Comments
DDT (Dichloro-diphenyl-thrichloroethane) Insecticidal properties were discovered by Swiss scientist, Paul Muller. Most widely used insecticide. Attacks nerves of insects but doesn’t cause immediate death. White amorphous powder. Contains 70 – 80% of para-para isomers, which is the most active fraction of DDT. Has residual action up to 18 months. Used as a residual spray.Least toxic organo-chlorine compound.
HCH (hexachlorocyclo-hexane) Synthesized by Michael Faraday. Normal HCH contains 13 – 16% of gamma isomer. Gamma-HCH or lindane has 99% gamma isomer.Short residual action – 3 months.
Malathion Least toxicity of all organophosphorus compounds. Used as an ultra-low volume spray.
Fenthion Also called baytex. Used as a residual spray.
Pyrethrum Vegetable origin – Chrysanthemum cinerariafolium. Nerve poison and is excellent as a space spray.No residual action.Synergistic action with DDT as space spray.

questions.text: You are performing intrauterine insemination during the ovulatory period in a patient with infertility. When will you expect implantation to occur?
questions.solution:
The fertilized ovum implants by 6–7 days in the uterine cavity.

Implantation involves: 

  •  Apposition: Blastocyst starts to establish contact with the uterine wall.
  •  Adhesion: Increase in the physical interaction between the blastocyst and the uterine epithelium.
  •  Invasion: Syncytiotrophoblasts and cytotrophoblasts penetrate and invade the endometrium.

Prior to implantation, the endometrium is primed with estrogen and progesterone from the corpus luteum. This uterine receptivity is maximal from the 20th - 24th days of the endometrial cycle. Failure of embryo transfer during this time period may result in repeated implantation failure in IVF patients. 

Adherence of the blastocyst to the uterine cavity is a result of interaction between the cell-surface receptors at the implantation site and the blastocyst receptors.

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR).

questions.text: Identify the skin condition shown in this photograph of a newborn.
questions.solution:
The skin condition shown in the above photograph of a newborn is seen in Harlequin Icthyosis.

  • Harlequin ichthyosis is the most devastating type of Autosomal Recessive Congenital Icthyosis.
  • It is due to mutations of the ABCA12 genes.
  • It is associated with thickened skin over nearly the entire body at birth.
  • Neonates are born with armour‐like skin (truncal plates with fissuring). The skin forms large, diamond-shaped plates that are separated by deep cracks.
  • Early in life constant supportive care is typically required.Treatments may include moisturizing cream, antibiotics, etretinate, or retinoids.

questions.text: A 12 year old boy came to the OPD with scald injury of arm. The lesion was  pink, oozing and painful to air and touch. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Scald injury(damage from contact with hot liquids) with pink, oozing and painful lesion is suggestive of a 2nd degree burn.Second-degree wounds is treated with daily dressing changes with topical antibiotics (Silver sulphadiazine cream), cotton gauze and elastic wraps.

Initial treatment for such burns is to clear exudate using a gauze and silver sulphadiazine cream dressing over the wound. The initial exudate needs to be managed by frequent changes of clean linen around the patient but, after a few days, a dry eschar forms, which then separates as the wound epithelialises.

 

Dupuytren’s classification of burns:

  • 1st-degree - involves epidermis,but intact epidermal barrier
  • 2nd-degree - involves epidermis and papillary dermis
  • Deep 2nd-degree - up to reticular dermis
  • 3rd-degree - involvement of subcutaneous fat
  • 4th-degree burns - into underlying muscle or bone

questions.text: A trauma patient suffers a renal laceration with urine extravasation. He is managed conservatively. However, after a few days he complaints of urinoma. The next best management for this patient would be?
questions.solution:
Ureteral stenting would be the next best management for this patient. The patient in the given question has renal laceration with urine extravasation, indicating that he had a grade 4 renal injury. Grade 4 renal injuries are managed conservatively with a repeat CT scan to check if the urinoma has resolved.

However, in the presence of persistent urinoma on repeat CT scans, they are managed with the placement of an internal ureteral stent. In patients not cured by ureteral stenting, percutaneous nephrostomy or transcutaneous drain may be required.

Urinoma refers to the extravasation of urine from a disruption of the urinary collecting system at any level from the calyx to the urethra.

Management of renal injuries:

- Grading of injury through CECT
- If hemodynamically stable: Conservative management - Bedrest & hemodynamic monitoring
                                                : In grade IV, a repeat CT scan to ensure the extravasation of urine has resolved.
- If hemodynamically unstable: Surgical exploration and repair
                                                    : In grade V, nephrectomy.

Related Pearl: American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) kidney Injury Scale

  Hematoma

>1 cm depth of renal cortex, without collecting system rupture or urinary extravasation

questions.text: A newborn assessed 5 minutes after birth is found to have a  heart rate of 90 beats/min and irregular respiration. The baby coughed on inserting a nasal catheter and was moving all his limbs actively. The body was pink with blue extremities. What is the Apgar score in this newborn?
questions.solution:
The Apgar score in this newborn is 7.

The Apgar score is a systematic way of assessing the infant after birth at 1 and 5 minutes of life. It gives a maximum score of 10 that indicates the newborn is in the best possible condition.

Scores between 0-3 require immediate resuscitation. Changes in the Apgar scores denote the response of the infant to resuscitation. If the score at 5 minutes remains less than 7, the infant should be assessed again every 5 minutes for the next 20 minutes.

The individual scores for all parameters given in the given clinical scenario are:

  • Appearance: Body is pink with blue extremities = 1
  • Pulse: 90 beats/min = 1
  • Grimace: Coughs on nasal catheter insertion = 2
  • Active motion: Moves all the limbs actively = 2
  • Respiratory effort - Irregular respiration = 1

Thus the total score in this baby is 7. 

Causes for low Apgar score are:

  • Fetal distress
  • Prematurity
  • Drugs like analgesics, narcotics, sedatives, magnesium sulfate
  • Acute cerebral trauma
  • Precipitous delivery
  • Airway obstruction (choanal atresia)  
  • Congenital pneumonia or sepsis
  • Hemorrhage- hypovolemia

False-negative Apgar score is seen in maternal acidosis and high fetal catecholamine levels.

questions.text: The following are non-depolarizing muscle relaxants except _________.
questions.solution: Suxamethonium or succinyl choline is a depolarizing muscle relaxant.

questions.text: Which of the following is true statement about Korsakoff syndrome?

choices.text: Triad of confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia
Loss of long term memory but intact personality
Anterograde amnesia with loss of recent memory
Loss of implicit memory and immediate recall

questions.solution:
In Korsakoff's psychosis, there is anterograde amnesia with loss of recent memory. 

Korsakoff's syndrome is a chronic amnestic syndrome that can follow Wernicke's syndrome. It is caused by thiamine deficiency that is associated with chronic alcohol abuse. The typical feature of this disease is anterograde amnesia with loss of recent memory in an alert and responsive patient. Patients with Korsakoff's syndrome also typically have a change in personality, with a lack of initiative, reduced spontaneity, and a lack of interest. 

The treatment is with 100 mg of thiamine orally for 3-12 months. Despite adequate treatment and nutritional support, very few of the patients fully recover. With treatment, patients may remain amnestic for up to 3 months, and then improve gradually during the next year.

Prolonged use of alcohol causes alcohol-induced persisting amnestic disorder with loss of short-term memory. When the symptoms are acute, it is called Wernicke's encephalopathy and when chronic, it leads to Korsakoff's syndrome. These conditions are caused due to thiamine deficiency and when they occur together, they are called Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.  

Other options 

Option A -Triad of confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia is seen in Wernicke's encephalopathy. There may also be vestibular dysfunction. Wernicke's encephalopathy is completely reversible. The treatment is parenteral administration of 100 mg thiamine for 1-2 weeks.

Option B - Personality is affected in Korsakoff's syndrome. Recent memory is affected more compared to long-term memory.

Option D - Implicit memory refers to memory that does not require conscious recollection. Implicit aspects of memory are preserved, however, some studies conclude that implicit memory may be intact or impaired depending on the specific task parameters.

questions.text: The ultrasound of a young woman with infertility is suggestive of a uterine anomaly. Which of the following is used to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Hysteroscopy with laparoscopy is used to confirm the diagnosis of the likely uterine anomaly

For infertility evaluation, hysteroscopy and laparoscopy can detect müllerian anomalies, screen for co-existent endometriosis, and exclude other tubal or uterine cavity pathology. Hysteroscopy combined with laparoscopy can confirm both the internal and the external contour of the uterus.

This approach can differentiate between a septate and a bicornuate uterus. On laparoscopy, the presence of a uterine fundus indicates that the uterus is septate, while absence indicates it is bicornuate. The capacity of each horn in a bicornuate uterus and the depth and thickness of uterine septum prior to surgical resection can also be assessed. 

MR imaging is the preferred imaging technique as it is highly accurate in the evaluation of müllerian anomalies. It clearly delineates both the internal and external uterine anatomy. Complex anomalies and common associations like renal or skeletal anomalies can be evaluated concurrently using MRI.

Other options:

Option A: Hysterosalpingography (HSG) provides information about the interior contour of the uterine cavity but cannot accurately visualize the external contour of the uterus. 

Option C: Laparoscopy alone as a diagnostic procedure cannot visualize the interior contour of a hollow viscus like the uterus. This can be done only with the help of hysteroscopy or imaging such as sonography, HSG, or MRI.

Option D: Transvaginal sonography is used for the initial detection of uterine anomalies causing infertility or spontaneous abortions. Complete evaluation of these anomalies is done by MR imaging.

questions.text: The instrument in the given image is used to take the sample from:
questions.solution:
The instrument in the given image is a cytobrush which is used to take sample from the endocervix for Pap smear.

Ayre’s spatula is used to take sample from squamocolumnar junction.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with pain over the lateral aspect of her right breast for the past 5 days. Examination finding is as shown in the image. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Mondor's disease. The image shows the presence of a subcutaneous cord and a narrow shallow groove along the side of the cord.

Mondor’s disease is the thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast and anterior chest wall. The most commonly involved vein is the lateral thoracic vein. Patients usually present with pain along the lateral chest wall and a tender, firm cord below the breast. It is a benign condition and gets resolved on its own within 4-6 weeks. Warm compresses and anti-inflammatory medicines can be used to reduce pain. If the symptoms persist despite medications, the affected segment of the vein can be excised.

Option A: Tietze’s syndrome is a benign inflammation of one or more costal cartilages.

Option B: Zuska disease is the subcutaneous abscess of the breast tissue beneath the areola of the nipple. It is also called a subareolar abscess.

Option D: Stewart–Treves Syndrome is characterized by lymphangiosarcoma in chronic long-standing lymphedema following mastectomy.

questions.text: Proper functioning of ICD tube is indicated by?

choices.text: Continuous air bubbles coming out of the underwater drain
Oscillation of water column in the tube

questions.solution:
Functioning of the ICD tube can be confirmed by seeing the oscillation of water column in the tube. 

During spontaneous respiration, the water level rises with inspiration and falls with expiration. Whereas during positive pressure ventilation, the opposite occurs. This oscillation is also known as tidaling.

An intercostal tube (ICD) is placed along the 5th intercostal space (ICS) in midaxillary line in adults and in paediactric age group it is placed at at 2nd ICS mid-clavicular line.

Other options:

Option A: Continous bubbling indicates an air leak in the drainage system, which should be corrected.

Option B: Chest X-ray is useful for assessing the position of the ICD tube inside the chest, not its functioning.

Option C: Auscultation is not useful for assessing the functioning of an ICD tube.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of the image given below?

choices.text: It is also known as thiersch graft
Only dressing is enough at donor site
Donor site can be reused before healing

questions.solution:
The image given depicts the harvesting of a split skin graft. The donor site can not be reused before healing.

The most preferable donor site is buttock in cosmetically sensitive individuals and children. The most commonly used donor site is the thigh.

  • The graft is taken from the donor site with a handheld Humby knife or electric dermatome.
  • Grafts are perforated to allow exudates to escape and improve ‘take’. It can further be meshed to allow expansion.
  • Grafts will take up only on the beds which are vascularized, hence preparation of wound bed is an essential step.
  • Skin grafts are completely dependent on nutrition on the tissue over which they are placed and can heal well over muscle, perichondrium, and periosteum. They do not take well over bone or cartilage or on tissue that has been irradiated or infected or is hypovascular.
  • A clean healthy wound bed with a meshed graft tied in place to stop movement will encourage take.
  • Presence of group A beta-hemolytic streptococci is contraindicated in grafting as it can destroy split grafts completely and also convert donor to full thickness defect.

questions.text: Presence of which of the following findings in the ECG of a patient would be inconsistent with a diagnosis of typical right atrial flutter?

choices.text: Positive p waves in lead V1
Positive sawtooth waves in leads II, III ,aVF
Conduction to the ventricles with 2:1 AV block

questions.solution:
Negative sawtooth waves in leads II, III, aVF are seen in typical right atrial flutter, not positive.

Common or typical atrial flutter is due to a circuit that revolves around the tricuspid valve annulus. ECG features of common atrial flutter:

  • Negative sawtooth flutter waves in leads II, III, and aVF
  • Positive P waves in lead V1
  • Atrial rate is between 240–300 beats/min
  • Conducts to the ventricles with 2:1 AV block

 Atypical atrial flutters are atrial tachycardias that are not dependent on conduction through the cavotricuspid isthmus.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding Foley catheter?

choices.text: French in foleys catheter refers to external circumference
Silicone foleys can be kept for maximum of 2 weeks
Three way foleys is used for instrumentation
If there is peri-urethral leakage of urine after inserting a foleys, first deflating the balloon is tried

questions.solution:
French with respect to Foley catheter refers to the external circumference of the catheter.

Option B: Latex Foley catheter can be kept for one week whereas silicone Foley catheter can be kept for up to 6 weeks (some studies say 2-3 months).

Option C: Three-way Foley catheter, shown below, is used for irrigation and helps in preventing clot retention following surgeries like TURP.

Option D: If there is peri-urethral leakage of urine after inserting a Foley, inflating the balloon slightly more or using a larger-sized Foley are the corrective measures.

Related Pearl: Foley's catheter

A Foley catheter is a thin, sterile tube inserted into the bladder to drain urine. Because it can be left in place in the bladder for a period of time, it is also called an indwelling catheter.

French scale corresponds to the external circumference in millimetres. French size divided by 3 will give the outer diameter of the catheter. 

Fr. size = 3 x d, where d is the outer diameter in mm. 

A 3 Fr. catheter will have a circumference of approximately 3 mm and a diameter of 1 mm. 

Note:

Colour of the foleys is the colour at the baloon port as shown in the figure below

questions.text: You suspect rheumatoid arthritis in a patient presenting with pain in her hands and having swelling and tenderness in proximal interphalangeal and metacarpophalangeal joints. What is the most specific marker for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The most specific marker for rheumatoid arthritis is anti-CCP antibody (cyclic citrullinated peptide).

Anti-CCP, ESR, and CRP values correlate with the disease activity.

Rheumatoid factor can occur in other autoimmune diseases as well and in chronic infections. Therefore it is not specific.

questions.text: Which is the nodal ministry for disaster management in India?

choices.text: Ministry of Health and Family Welfare

questions.solution:
The Ministry of Home Affairs is the nodal ministry for disaster management at the Centre except for dealing with droughts which is under the purview of the Ministry of Agriculture.

Other parts of the Indian government involved in disaster management are the Emergency Medical Relief Wing under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare.

The Indian Meteorological Department plays a role in mitigation of disaster and its preparedness.

questions.text: Binge-eating disorder is characterized by all except _____

choices.text: Eating much more rapidly than normal
Eating large amounts of food when not feeling physically hungry

questions.solution:
Binge-eating disorder does not involve activites (like self-induced vomiting) for compensating over eating.

The binge-eating episodes are associated with the following:

  • Eating much more rapidly than normal.
  • Eating until feeling uncomfortably full.
  • Eating large amounts of food when not feeling physically hungry.
  • Eating alone because of feeling embarrassed by how much one is eating.
  • Feeling disgusted with oneself, depressed, or very guilty afterward.

Related Pearl: Eating Disorders
