questions.text:
Which of the following features help in differentiating nephroblastoma from neuroblastoma?

A. Presents with painless abdominal mass, not crossing the midline

B. Dancing eyes-dancing feet syndrome can be seen

C. WAGR syndrome with WT-1 gene mutation have bilateral lesions

D. Spontaneous regression can be seen even in later stages

E. Drooping lily sign on IVP
questions.solution:
A and C are the correct statements for nephroblastoma, also known as Wilm's tumor. 

The differentiating features between neuroblastoma and nephroblastoma is tabulated below - 

                 Neuroblastoma               Nephroblastoma (Wilm’s tumor) 
In children Most common abdominal malignancy  Most common renal malignancy (2nd most common abdominal malignancy) 
Origin Neural crest cells arising from an adrenal gland or paravertebral sympathetic ganglia (extrarenal)  Intrarenal origin is seen due to undifferentiated mesoderm 
Gene mutation N-myc amplification WT-1, WT-2; Associated with WAGR syndrome, Beckwith Weidman syndrome
Age  Peak at 5 years of age Seen around 2-4 years of age
C/F Painful, fixed abdominal mass - crossing the midline Painless, mobile abdomen mass that does not cross the midline along with hematuria
Constitutional symptoms Present like raccoon eyes, blueberry muffin lesion, opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome Absent
Tumor margin Poorly marginated mass; Homer-Wright rosettes seen on HPE; Drooping lily sign on IVP Well-circumscribed mass - 'claw sign' seen on IVP/CECT
Intratumor calcification Common  Rare, seen along the peripheries
Vascular involvement It encases the vessels but do not invade them - elevates the aorta from the vertebral column  Dispaces the adjacent structures with vascular invasion along renal veins/ IVC (not considered metastasis) 
Metastasis Long bones, skull, liver. Lung mets are rarely seen.  Lungs > lymph nodes

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman complains of numbness of her hands, generalized weakness, and easy fatiguability. She had undergone a gastrectomy recently. She looks very pale and her peripheral smear reveals the following findings shown below. If untreated, which of the following will be seen in the patient?

choices.text: Large fiber neuropathy causing loss of proprioception
Large fiber neuropathy causing stabbing pain
Small fiber neuropathy causing loss of temperature sense
Small fiber neuropathy causing loss of vibration sense

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of numbness, generalized weakness, easy fatiguability suggest anemia. The history of gastrectomy and the peripheral smear showing large hypersegmented neutrophil and macro-ovalocytes depicting macrocytic anemia is suggestive of vitamin B12 deficiency. The patient is at risk of developing large fiber neuropathy causing loss of proprioception.

Vitamin B12 deficiency typically leads to large fiber neuropathy which presents with loss of vibration and loss of proprioception. Small nerve fibres are spared in B12 deficiency.

Pernicious anemia is a common cause of vitamin B12 deficiency. The other causes of vitamin B12 deficiency are gastrectomy, gastric bypass surgery, inflammatory bowel disease, pancreatic insufficiency, malabsorption of cobalamin from food, and so on.

The clinical features include easy fatiguability, numbness of hands, loss of vibration and proprioception, hyperreflexia, and loss of ankle reflexes. 

Investigations reveal anemia, macrocytosis, and reduced cobalamin levels. Serum methylmalonic acid and homocysteine are elevated. Antibodies to the intrinsic factor may be seen in pernicious anemia.

Peripheral smear shows marked variation in red cell size (anisocytosis) and shape (poikilocytosis). The presence of red cells that are macrocytic and oval (macro-ovalocytes) is highly characteristic. Neutrophils are also larger than normal and show nuclear hypersegmentation, having five or more nuclear lobules instead of the normal three to four

Treatment can vary according to the regimen. One regimen consists of intramuscular injections of 1000 micrograms of cyanocobalamin weekly for a month, and then monthly thereafter.  

Note: Smaller-diameter myelinated and unmyelinated fibers transmit pain and temperature sensation. Hence, small fiber neuropathies present as temperature loss or burning or stabbing pain.

questions.text: Examination of a young man reveals a firm enlargement of the epididymis with normal-feeling testes and beading of the vas deferens. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Anti-tubercular chemotherapy if a primary focus is found, with epididymectomy
Confirmation of genital TB with PCR

questions.solution:
In the clinical scenario above, the presence of a firm enlargement of the epididymis with normal-feeling testes and beading of the vas deferens is specific to genital tuberculosis (TB). The next best step is confirmation with polymerase chain reaction (PCR). 

Secondary tuberculous epididymitis may resolve when the primary focus is treated; hence, a course of anti-tubercular therapy must be completed even if there is no evidence of disease elsewhere.

questions.text: While examining a patient’s pulse, you note a tapping impulse when you raise his arm above his head. Which of the following conditions would you not suspect in the patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of water hammer pulse which is not seen in left-sided heart failure.  

Collapsing pulse/Watson’s water hammer pulse is a rapidly rising pulse that collapses suddenly. This is because arterial pressure falls rapidly during late systole and diastole. It is also called Corrigan's pulse.

The various causes of the collapsing pulse include:

  • Physiologically, it can be present in fever and pregnancy. This is attributed to the combination of increased cardiac output and the reduction in systemic vascular resistance. 
  • Cardiac lesions such as aortic regurgitation, patent ductus arteriosus, systolic hypertension, marked bradycardia, aneurysm of sinus of Valsalva.
  • High-output states such as anemia, cor pulmonale, thyrotoxicosis, arteriovenous fistula, Paget's disease, beriberi, and liver cirrhosis (secondary to chronic alcoholism).

questions.text: Pyridoxine co-administration is essential for which of the following drugs used for treating Wilson’s disease?
questions.solution:
Pyridoxine co-administration is essential for the Penicillamine drug used for treating Wilson’s disease.

Wilson's disease is a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by defective hepatic copper excretion, leading to copper accumulation in the liver, brain, and other organs. It typically presents in adolescents or young adults with hepatic symptoms such as hepatitis, cirrhosis, or liver failure, or with neurological manifestations including tremors, dystonia, dysarthria, and psychiatric disturbances. Kayser-Fleischer rings, copper deposits in the cornea, are a hallmark finding. Diagnosis is confirmed by low serum ceruloplasmin, elevated urinary copper excretion, and genetic testing. Treatment includes copper-chelating agents like penicillamine or trientine(Option C), along with zinc therapy(Option A) to reduce intestinal copper absorption. Early detection and lifelong treatment can prevent disease progression and complications.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient who was a chronic smoker came with complaints of swelling in the lip as shown below. On examination, an ulcerative mass was seen, as shown in the image below, and a submental lymph node was palpable. Which of the following is true about the given condition?

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type
Women above 60 years of age are commonly affected
Vermilion border of the upper lip is the common site
Exposure to chemicals like benzene is a common cause

questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette and the image are suggestive of lip cancer. Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of lip cancer.

Lip cancer most commonly occurs in men from 50 to 80 years of age. Exposure to the sun and smoking are the main risks factors of lip cancer. More than 90 percent of lip cancers are squamous cell carcinoma.

Most lip cancers occur in the lower lip followed by the upper lip and commissure. The most common site is the vermilion border of the lower lip. But commonly occurring cancer in the upper lip is basal cell carcinoma.

Ulcerative lesion on the vermilion border of the lower lip is the most common clinical manifestation. Mass can extend and fix on the underlying bone. There is a loss of sensation of the skin over the chin due to the involvement of mental nerves. Submental and submandibular nodes are frequently involved.

The early-stage disease can be treated by surgery or radiation therapy. Post-surgical irradiation is indicated in advanced-stage disease. For defects of more than one-third of the lip, surgical excision followed by lip augmentation surgery is needed.

questions.text: A 33-year-old female patient comes with complaints of menorrhagia for the past 3 months. The duration and regularity of her menstrual cycles are normal. Non-hormonal management has been tried without success. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Hormonal therapy is the next best step in the given scenario of menorrhagia that is unresponsive to non-hormonal therapy. 

Menorrhagia is defined as heavy but regular menstrual bleeding. It can be acute (<6 months) or chronic (>6 months).

It is managed as follows:

  • Medical - first line of treatment.  
    • NSAIDs
    • Tranexamic acid  
    • OCPs/progestogens - if non-hormonal management fails 
    • Mirena IUCD
    • Blood transfusion, if required 
  • Surgical - if medical management fails, depending on the diagnosis:
    • Endometrial ablation - hysteroscopic, TCRE, RITEA, microwave, NovaSure, etc
    • Uterine artery embolization
    • Uterine tamponade
    • Hysterectomy - if all minimally invasive methods fail

questions.text: A multigravida presents to the labour room at 40 weeks of gestation. On examination, you notice that the fetal head has appeared at the vulva. Which of the following manoeuvres can be used to assist the delivery of the head?
questions.solution:
Ritgen's manoeuvre is done for delivery of head in normal labour.

This manoeuvre is done when the head distends the vulva and perineum enough to open the vaginal introitus to a diameter of >5 cm. A towel is draped and a gloved hand may be used to exert forward pressure on the chin of the fetus through the perineum. The other hand exerts pressure superiorly against the occiput.

This manoeuvre allows controlled delivery of the head.

questions.text: The most common extraintestinal manifestation of celiac disease is :
questions.solution:
The most common extraintestinal manifestation of celiac disease is dermatitis herpetiformis (DH).

DH is characterised by intensely pruritic small papules and vesicles on the extensor surfaces of extremities, buttocks and neck. It can be considered as a celiac disease of the skin.

Other extraintestinal manifestations of celiac disease are:

  • Anaemia
  • Low bone density
  • Ataxia
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Infertility

Celiac disease is often associated with other conditions such as type 1 diabetes mellitus, autoimmune thyroid disease, IgA deficiency, bird fancier's lung and Down’s syndrome.

questions.text: What is the following image of a barium swallow suggestive of?
questions.solution:
The image shows a markedly dilated esophagus and characteristic “bird's beak” appearance (distal narrowing), which is suggestive of achalasia cardia.

Achalasia cardia is caused due to the degeneration of the neurons in the myenteric plexus of the esophagus. This degeneration results in the failure of relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) on swallowing.

The patients present with a classic triad of dysphagia, regurgitation, and weight loss. The dysphagia initially begins with liquid foods and then progresses to solid foods. As the food gets accumulated in the esophagus, patients may complain of halitosis. With further progression of the disease, the patients may develop pneumonia, lung abscess, etc.

The initial diagnosis is made by barium swallow or endoscopy, which shows the presence of dilated esophagus due to the constriction of the lower esophageal sphincter (bird-beak appearance). The gold standard test to confirm achalasia cardia is esophageal manometry.

questions.text: A 28-year female presents to your OPD with complaints of vaginal discharge. She is sexually active with her partner. Given below is the image of a smear prepared from the vaginal discharge of a patient. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of clue cells on microscopy is suggestive of bacterial vaginosis.

It is caused due to the alteration in the normal vaginal flora. There is a decrease in the number of lactobacilli. These lactobacilli reduce the pH and release hydrogen peroxide which is antibacterial. Therefore, a decrease in the number of lactobacilli leads to an increase in the number of other organisms like Hemophilus vaginalis, Gardnerella, Mobiluncus, and Mycoplasma hominis. 

According to Amsel's criteria, the discharge has the following characteristics. 

  • White milky non-viscous discharge, adherent to the vaginal wall
  • The pH of the discharge is more than 4.5
  • Fishy odor when mixed with 10% KOH. This is called the Whiff test.
  • Presence of clue cells-the epithelial cells have a fuzzy border due to the adherence of bacteria.
  • Decrease in the number of lactobacilli and increase in the number of Gardnerella and other bacteria.

It is treated with 500 mg of metronidazole twice daily for 7 days.

Shown below is the Gram-stained smear of vaginal discharge of a patient diagnosed with bacterial vaginosis. It reveals vaginal epithelial cells that have a fuzzy border due to the adherence of bacteria. These are called clue cells.

Gram‐negative intracellular diplococci as shown below indicates infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae

 

Below is an image of trophozoite form of Trichomonas vaginalis

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

  Bacterial vaginosis Trichomonas vaginitis

Candidal vaginitis
Causative organism  Altered vaginal flora- increased concentration of Gardnerella vaginalis Trichomonas vaginalis Candida albicans
Aetiology Increased vaginal pH Sexually transmitted Decreased immunity
Sexual transmission No Yes No
Discharge Fishy, thin, yellow Frothy, green Curdy, white
Symptoms Fishy odour, no itching Itching and burning Itching, burning
pH >4.5 >4.5 <4.5
Speculum No vaginal epithelium inflammation Strawberry cervix Inflamed-epithelium
KOH Positive Whiff test The whiff test can be positive. Pseudohyphae seen.
Wet mount Clue cells. No WBCs seen Motile trichomaonads, WBCs seen WBCs seen
Treatment Metronidazole or Clindamycin Metronidazole, treat partner also Oral or vaginal azole, no need to treat partner.

questions.text: For the diagnosis of resistant hypertension, the patient should have uncontrolled hypertension despite taking three antihypertensive drugs. This should include at least one:
questions.solution:
Resistant hypertension is defined as blood pressure persistently >140/90 mmHg despite taking three or more antihypertensive agents, including a diuretic.

Resistant hypertension is more common in patients aged >60 years than in younger patients. Resistant hypertension may be related to:

  • Pseudohypertension- high office blood pressures and lower home blood pressures
  • Non-adherence to therapy
  • Identifiable causes of hypertension such as obesity and excessive alcohol intake.
  • Secondary causes of hypertension

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient, during his routine annual checkup, is found to have an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 40 mm in diameter on USG. Which of the following is true about the management of this patient?

choices.text: Surgery is indicated if aneurysmal diameter is >55mm
Urgently wheel the patient to OT for surgery
Surgery is indicated only if aneurysm is >77mm

questions.solution:
Surgery is indicated in asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm only if its diameter is more than 55mm.

If the diameter is less than 55mm, regular ultrasound monitoring is required. This is because elective open surgery has a higher rate of mortality when compared to conservative management for aneurysms of size < 55mm.

questions.text: A 42-year old alcoholic and a chronic smoker presented with bouts of vomiting and stabbing pain in the epigastrium. He was binge drinking shortly before the symptoms started. He is febrile and tachycardic. The given findings were seen on bedside radiological imaging. Which among the following is a likely cause of this?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the diagnosis is suggestive of Pneumoperitoneum and the likely cause for this would be peptic ulcer perforation.

Gastric ulcers are more prone to perforate than bleed. Thus, these perforations lead to pneumoperitoneum which is an emergency and warrants immediate surgical intervention. 

The classical description of a patient with a perforated peptic ulcer is described in three stages:

Stage of peritonism: Initial 6 hours - patient presents with an acute burning epigastric pain with or without vomiting. Leakage of gastric acid into the peritoneal cavity causes diaphragmatic irritation which may lead to pain referred to the shoulder tip (Option D) and tracking of fluid in the right para-colic gutter may lead to right iliac fossa pain. Abdominal guarding with diminished abdominal movements on respiration is noted and the patient avoids movement to prevent pain. Tachycardia (Option B) is noted but pyrexia does not set in.
Stage of reaction: the symptoms temporarily subside due to the dilution of the exudate in the peritoneal cavity but abdominal rigidity remains (Option A).
Stage of diffuse peritonitis: sunken face, hollow cheeks, dry mucous membranes (facies hippocratica) with fever, tachycardia, low volume pulse and increasing abdominal distension.
Initial management includes intravenous (IV) fluid therapy, cessation of oral intake, and administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics. Perforation is an indication for surgical exploration. Perforations less than 1 cm can be closed primarily with an omental patch repair, while larger perforations may require a distal gastrectomy with a roux-en-y reconstruction. Patients require prolonged PPI therapy postoperatively.

 Other options: 

A. Tension pneumothorax - presents with a rapid hemodynamic compromise with absent breath sounds. Pneumoperitoneum rarely is caused by pneumothorax, and downward displacement of air is more likely seen in retroperitoneal spaces.

C. Boerhaave syndrome or spontaneous esophageal rupture - occurs in alcoholics after binge drinking, due to forced vomiting from the closed glottis.  Pneumomediastinum and subcutaneous emphysema are seen here. 

D. Mallory Weis tear - longitudinal mucosal tear resulting in upper GI bleeding. It is commonly seen in alcoholics.

questions.text: Which class of ovarian tumor does clear cell carcinoma of the ovary belong to?
questions.solution:
Clear cell carcinoma of the ovary is a type of epithelial cell tumor.

Epithelial ovarian tumors arise from the mesoepithelial cells present on the ovarian surface. 80% of all ovarian cancers are epithelial cancers.

Clear cell carcinoma is also known as mesonephroid tumor. The histopathology of clear cell carcinoma reveals large cuboidal epithelial cells with abundant clear cytoplasm characteristically forming tubules, glands, and small cystic spaces. These cystic spaces are lined by hobnail cells. They are clear cells showing large dark nuclei protruding into the lumen. It is a highly malignant tumor. 

Malignant epithelial tumors can spread widely via transcoelomic spread. It can spread through the capsule onto the peritoneal surface, omentum, intestinal viscera, and sub-diaphragmatic space. An ascitic tap will reveal blood-stained fluid with tumor cells. It may also spread to the para-aortic nodes and cause metastasis in the other ovary, liver, lungs, and gastrointestinal tract.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her HbA1c level is 11.1%. What is the initial drug of choice?
questions.solution:
Insulin is the best initial drug of choice when HbA1c is > 9% at diagnosis. 

Insulin is used in the treatment of type 2 diabetes in the following cases:

  • Inadequate glycemic control with 2 or more oral agents
  • HbA1c > 9% at diagnosis

In patients with HbA1c < 9%, metformin is the drug of choice.
